talk.start.para: Senator Patterson(from 21 citizens)

—On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move that the following delegated legislation, a list of which I shall hand to the Clerk, be disallowed:

speech.para: 1. Australian Sports Drug Agency Drug Testing (Scheme A) Orders 1999 made under regulation 7 of the Australian Sports Drug Agency Regulations 1999.
2. Australian Sports Drug Agency Regulations 1999, as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No.159 and made under the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 .
3. Determination No.1/1999—Determination of Education and Courses made under subsections 3(1) and 5D(1) of the Student Assistance Act 1973 .
4. Exemption No. CASA 25/1999 made under regulation 308 of the Civil Aviation Regulations 1988
5. Fisheries Management Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.3), as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No.130 and made under the Fisheries Management Act 1991 .
6. Health Insurance Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.3), as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No.157 and made under the Health Insurance Act 1973 .
7. Hearing Services Amendment Rules of Conduct 1999 (No.1) made under subsection 17(1) of the Hearing Services Administration Act 1997 .
8. Native Title (Prescribed Bodies Corporate) Regulations 1999, as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No.151 and made under the Native Title Act 1993 .

[Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provisions apply: must be resolved within 15 sitting days after today or the Determinations, Exemption, Orders, Regulations and Rules will be deemed to have been disallowed.]
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.
Leave granted.

para.inline: Australian Sports Drug Agency Drug Testing (Scheme A) Orders 1999

speech.para: The Orders establish the administrative framework for the collection and sampling of drug tests performed on competitors in sport.

Section 8 of the Orders provides that substantial, rather than strict, compliance with the provisions of these Orders will generally be sufficient but does not indicate who is to decide what constitutes substantial compliance.

Subsection 10(2) of the Orders obliges a competitor to comply with `any instructions given by a chaperone during the sample collection process' but does not limit those instructions to such as may be reasonably required in the circumstances.

Section 11 of the Orders gives to the drug control officer in charge of the collection of a urine sample a discretion as to the information which he or she may record on the drug testing form. No reason is given for this discretion or why the officer is not required to record certain information, and no other.

Subsection 28(2) to (6) of the Orders list a number of matters which a competitor and a drug control officer must carry out, but then, in subsection 28(7), the drug control officer is given the discretion as to the instructions which may be given to the competitor.

Subsections 29(3) and 43(3) provide that the respective subsections (4) apply if, for example, the pH of a sample is lower than 5 or higher than 7. But the relevant subsections (4) then require the drug control officer to deny the evidence that he or she has received, and treat the sample as if the pH were not lower than 5 or higher than 7.

Subsection 49(2) of the Orders deems `a courier in the normal course of business' to be a secure means of transporting a sample to an accredited laboratory. However, neither the Act, the Regulations, nor the Orders provide a definition of such a courier. Also, if a drug control officer decides not to use such a courier, he or she is required to see to the transport of samples `by means which will ensure [their] safe arrival'. The section, however, does not provide for the means by which the officer is to fulfil this requirement.
Subsection 51(2) of the Orders obliges a drug control officer to store samples overnight in `a secure place', but neither the Act, the Regulations nor the Orders apparently defines such a place.

Section 57 of the Orders deals with the testing of part B of a sample, if the result of testing part A of the sample is positive. The section does not indicate what an accredited laboratory is to do with part B of a sample if, either the test of part A is negative, or the Agency does not instruct the laboratory to test part B.

Subsection 60(2) of the Orders requires the Agency to remove details of a person's name, etc from the Scheme A register if it turns out that the person was not a competitor. It might be thought that the Agency should satisfy itself before carrying out the testing program on a person whether they were a competitor or not.
The Committee is concerned that the discretions about what is being recorded in the Register may infringe on the privacy of the athletes.

Subsection 61(1) of the Orders appears to incorporate into the Orders various lists of prohibited drugs and doping methods kept by sporting administration bodies `as in force from time to time'. This provision may be contrary to subsection 49A(1) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 .

para.inline: Australian Sports Drug Agency Regulations 1999 Statutory Rules 1999 No.159

speech.para: These Statutory Rules create a single drug testing scheme for competitors in sport.

Regulations 8 and 9 allow for the appointment of, respectively, `drug control officials' and `chaperones'. Since, by virtue of subregulation 9(2), a drug control official is also a chaperone, and since neither need have any special qualifications or attributes, as they need only be a `person', it is difficult to see the reason for the two types of officials.

Subregulations 12(1) and 13(2) seek to ensure that a person taking a sample from a competitor will report to the Australian Sports Drug Agency any personal interest in the collection of the sample. Subregulations 12(2) and 13(3) nevertheless permit the Agency to allow the person taking the sample to continue with that task.

para.inline: Conditions of service—persons appointed by a sporting administrative body

speech.para: Subregulation 13(2) requires the Agency to make sure that the conditions of service of persons appointed by a sporting administrative body contain particular terms. However, it is suggested that this provision may not fulfil its apparent purpose. There is no requirement, for instance, that the conditions of service must be immutable, and it is difficult to see how the Agency could monitor the conditions of service, at any particular time, of those appointed by other, outside, bodies.

Subregulations 18(2) and (3) give the Agency a discretion as to whether to communicate with a competitor through an interpreter. It might be thought that if a competitor is `unable to receive or understand [a] request' (see subregulation 18(2)), or is `unable to understand English' (see subregulation 18(3)), the Agency should be required to make all reasonable efforts to ensure, by whatever means, that its request is understood.

para.inline: Australian Sports Drug Medical Advisory Committee

speech.para: By virtue of paragraph 65(2)(b) read with subregulation 65(3), the Chairman of the Australian Sports Drug Medical Advisory Committee must convene a meeting of the Committee if he or she receives, among other things, an oral request therefor from the Agency. The Committee suggests that it would conduce to better administration if such requests were required to be in writing.

Regulation 80 permits the Agency to delegate `all or any of its powers except [this] power to delegate' to, among others, a drug control official or a chaperone, and regulation 82 gives a drug control official a similar power to delegate to a chaperone. However, it is apparent that, by virtue of the definitions of drug control official and chaperone in regulation 3, there is no limit by reason of office or attribute on the persons who may be appointed to the position of drug control official or chaperone. The Committee suggests that these powers of delegation are too wide, and that delegations should, for instance, be limited to employees of the Agency.

The Explanatory Statement to the Regulations stated that the `Privacy Commissioner has been consulted [about the Regulations] but notes that compliance with the Privacy Act 1988 will depend upon the way Drug Testing Scheme A is implemented'. The Orders appear to implement Scheme A, but the Explanatory Statement to these Orders states that the `Privacy Commissioner has been consulted on the [Orders] but notes that compliance with the Privacy Act 1988 will depend upon the way the Orders are implemented'.

The Explanatory Statements for both the Regulations and the Orders give a broad picture only. These statements are deficient, in that there is no detailed explanation of each individual regulation. There is also no indication whether these Regulations and Orders are consistent with standard testing orders used throughout the international community and whether international and domestic sporting bodies were consulted about the testing scheme.

para.inline: Determination No.1/1999—Determination of Education and Courses made under subsections 3(1) and 5D(1) of the Student Assistance Act 1973

speech.para: This Determination specifies those education institutions and the courses offered therein which are approved for the purposes of the Act. Despite having been made on 22 June 1999, the Determination is deemed to have commenced on 1 July 1998. Unfortunately, the Explanatory Statement does not provide any indication of whether this retrospectivity may adversely affect any person other than the Commonwealth. The Explanatory Statement also does not advise whether the Determination which is revoked by this instrument, and which was apparently defective, operated to the disadvantage of any person.

para.inline: Exemption No. CASA 25/1999 made under regulation 308 of the Civil Aviation Regulations 1988

speech.para: CASA 25/1999 exempts Brumby pilotless aircraft from compliance with most of the Civil Aviation Regulations while a member of the aeronautical engineering department of the University of Sydney flies them for developmental testing purposes. Clause 5 of the Conditions, subject to which this Exemption has been granted, requires a flight tester who is flying a Brumby pilotless aircraft to `ensure that persons operating ultralight aircraft at Medway are notified not less than 24 hours before flights begin under this exemption'. This provision may be unreasonable as it may not be possible for a flight tester to know every person who planned to fly an ultralight aircraft on the following day.

para.inline: Fisheries Management Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.3) Statutory Rules 1999 No.130

speech.para: These Statutory Rules amend the Principal Regulations in relation to the Christmas Island Fishery, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Fishery and the Macquarie Island Fishery. One purpose of these Statutory Rules is to set an application fee for entry to the Macquarie Island Fishery. That fee, of $5350, is described in the Explanatory Statement as being `significantly higher than the usual fee' for such an application. The explanation given for this higher fee is merely `the process involved', but the higher fee is also justified on the basis of the costs that the AFMA will incur in that process. There is, however, no indication, in the Explanatory Statement, of the degree to which this fee is higher than others, nor is there any indication of the nature of the process involved in considering applications.

para.inline: Health Insurance Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.3) Statutory Rules 1999 No.157

speech.para: These Statutory Rules clarify provisions of the Principal Regulations. Items 1 to 5 of Schedule 1 to these Regulations make machinery amendments to ensure that the references to items in the Health Insurance Regulations correctly refer to items in the General Medical Services Table and the Diagnostic Imaging Services Table. The Explanatory Statement advises that this is to `reflect recent changes to the tables where new items have been added and superfluous items have been removed from the tables'. The Statement does not, however, advise whether the incorrect referencing between the item numbers, which appeared in the Regulations and those appearing in the Tables, resulted in any disadvantage to members of the public.

para.inline: Hearing Services Amendment Rules of Conduct 1999 (No.1) made under subsection 17(1) of the Hearing Services Administration Act 1997

speech.para: These Rules prescribe fees for the maintenance and replacement of hearing devices that have been supplied to voucher-holders free of charge. Sched ule 1 to the Rules provides for a fee of $30 for the maintenance and replacement of batteries in a device that has been provided free of charge to a voucher-holder who is a participant in the voucher system. Prior to the making of this instrument, a person who was a voucher-holder, and a dependant of a participant in the voucher system, paid a reduced amount for the maintenance and replacement of batteries in a hearing device that had been provided free of charge to the voucher-holder (Hearing Services Rules of Conduct 1997, subparagraph 20(2)(c)(ii), as in force up to 30 June 1999). One effect of the amendment made by these Rules is to remove the reference to this category of person from the Rules of Conduct.

para.inline: Native Title (Prescribed Bodies Corporate) Regulations 1999 Statutory Rules 1999 No.151

speech.para: These Statutory Rules provide the necessary administrative framework for the operation of aspects of the Native Title Act 1993 .

Subregulation 8(3) provides that a `prescribed body corporate must ensure that the common law holders [of native title] understand the purpose and nature of a proposed native title decision'. This provision appears to be unworkable.

Paragraph 9(3)(a) allows a document to be good evidence of consultation with and consent by the common law holders of native title if it is signed by `at least 5 members of the prescribed body corporate'. However, neither the regulation, nor the Explanatory Statement, indicates why five members of such a body are regarded as sufficiently representative of the group.

Paragraph 10(3)(a) provides that a person is entitled to a copy of a document if the person `has a substantial interest in the decision to which the document relates'. However, r.10 does not indicate who is to determine that question, nor by what means the determination is to be made.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Migration Act 1958, and for other purposes.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
This bill provides for the extension of the current statutory self-regulation framework of the migration advice industry until March 2003 and includes several measures to enhance its effectiveness.
In 1997 the Government decided to move the migration advice industry to self-regulation through a period of statutory self-regulation.
The Government agreed to consider a further move to voluntary self-regulation at the end of two years.

Statutory self-regulation is subject to a sunset clause and ceases to operate on 21 March 2000. The Government was therefore committed to reviewing the effectiveness of the operation of statutory self-regulation before that date.
The Government has now reviewed the operation of the current arrangements to decide on the most appropriate regulatory model for the migration advice industry beyond March 2000.

The Government has found that the industry is not yet ready to move to voluntary self-regulation in view of continuing significant consumer protection concerns, national interest issues and the special nature of the migration advice industry.
In particular, the Government has significant concerns about the vulnerability of the client group to exploitation, and the ethics and conduct of a small group in the industry.

Given the vulnerability of clients and the potential for malpractice in the industry, it is clear that voluntary regulation of the industry would not be desirable or viable at this stage and that statutory self-regulation should continue.
The review confirmed the appropriateness of the Government's decision to introduce the existing statutory self-regulation framework.

The review found that the MIA—that is, the Migration Institute of Australia—acting as the Migration Agents Registration Authority (the MARA) has demonstrated its commitment to the objectives of consumer protection and its capacity to undertake industry regulation.

The MIA, acting as the MARA , has already established sound disciplinary and mediation processes that should continue to increase consumer protection, competence and ethical standards in the industry.
The review of statutory self-regulation was undertaken by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and steered by an independent Reference group.
A number of members of the Reference group had assisted the Government in the 1997 review of the industry.
As in 1997, the most recent Reference group was chaired by Mr Ian Spicer, former President of the Confederation of Australian Industry.
The Reference group included individuals with a broad understanding of the industry.
In particular:
one member was nominated by the MIA;
another member had considerable knowledge of community concerns; and
a further member was formerly a Minister for Immigration, that is, the Hon John Hodges.
The review gave careful consideration to the performance of the existing arrangements and sought input from over 40 stakeholders.
Particular consideration was given to the views expressed by the industry body.
In its role as the MARA, the MIA has indicated its strong support for the measures included in this bill.
In extending statutory self-regulation, the Government has recognised the achievements of the MARA in establishing the self-regulation framework.
All stakeholders have expressed support for the continuation of the existing statutory self-regulation framework at this stage of industry development.

In deciding that it is not yet time to move to voluntary self-regulation, the Government has taken account of the fact that the industry is at an early stage of maturity and there is only limited experience with the current arrangements.
Statutory self-regulation has been in place for fewer than 18 months. Some major elements, such as the continuing professional development requirements, have been in place for fewer than 6 months.
While the MIA's coverage of the industry has expanded substantially since statutory self-regulation was introduced, there are still only 25 per cent of registered agents who are members of the MIA.
This would not be sufficient to support a move to voluntary self-regulation when current arrangements expire in March 2000.
There will be another review of the industry in two to three years to re-examine the state of the industry and gauge its progress.
I would expect that at that time it will be possible to assess how far the industry can develop and how well it can sustain voluntary self regulation.
The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will be setting milestones in conjunction with the MARA to monitor the development of the industry in relation to:
improvements in competence and ethical standards;
the extent of MIA industry coverage and its performance in the industry regulation role; and
changes to consumer awareness that would support a less regulated environment.

The extension of statutory self-regulation until March 2003 will provide an opportunity for some of the important industry values being promoted by the MIA and the MARA to be more firmly entrenched in industry practice.
Many industry stakeholders have confirmed, to the review, the need for continued improvements in the ethical standards and competence in the industry and protection available to consumers.

This bill includes two new measures to this end. Other measures will be addressed through amendments which require more complex drafting, which I expect to introduce next year, and through regulation amendments.
The bill includes amendments to make publication requirements relating to decisions by the MARA to cancel or suspend an agent's registration more cost-effective.

Currently the MARA is required to publish full details of any decisions to cancel or suspend an agent's registration in the Saturday edition of a national daily publication, including the evidence for its decisions and its findings on any material details of fact.

Although the intentions behind this requirement are to protect existing and potential clients and to promote agent and community understanding of appropriate ethical standards in the industry, in practice, the requirement has resulted in costly advertisements swamped by excessive detail, with little visual impact and little communicative value.

The amendments in this bill maintain the basic requirements that the MARA should publish its decisions to suspend or cancel an agent's registration and the grounds for its decisions in prescribed publications.

However, the MARA will no longer be required to publish full details of the evidence and its findings on material facts relevant to the decision, saving money for the industry body and thus ultimately agents and consumers.

The amendments will also give the MARA the discretionary power to publish some or all of this detailed information about cancellation or suspension decisions in an expanded variety of formats and methods of publications relevant to its target audiences, including on the Internet and in specialist newspapers.
The amendments will also give protection to other persons publishing in good faith a copy or fair summary of MARA's decisions.

Together, these amendments will mean that the MARA will be able to use appropriate channels to communicate more effectively—to clients, agents and the general community—its decisions to suspend or cancel an agent's registration.

This bill also provides the MARA with powers to ensure that clients of inactive and deceased agents are not unduly disadvantaged by the agent becoming inactive or as a result of the death of the agent.

Therefore, the MARA will be able to require certain agents—for example, those whose registration has been suspended or cancelled—to provide copies of relevant client documents to the MARA for forwarding to clients.

This will enable clients to continue their cases with another agent or to manage their cases themselves, ensuring that critical deadlines in relation to a client's visa applications or reviews of applications are not ignored.
The MARA's ability to do this will be discretionary. There may be cases such as multi-agent practices in which the MARA does not need to intervene.
However, the relevance of this power was highlighted by the recent closure of the largest migration advice firm in Australia.
Fortunately, this company voluntarily made files available to the MARA.

However, if such a situation occurs after the commencement of the bill, and if the firm or agent does not make files available to the MARA voluntarily, the powers in this bill will provide a basis for the MARA to require that relevant documents be copied, and that those copies be given to clients.

The closure of this particular migration agency is being closely evaluated by my Department and the MARA to identify any further issues which may need to be addressed within the industry regulation arrangements.

In conclusion, this bill extends the protection that is available to consumers under the current arrangements and will continue the progress that has been achieved in the last 18 months towards enhancing competence and ethical standards in the industry.
I commend this bill to the Chamber.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned till the first day of sitting in the summer sittings 1999, in accordance with standing order 111.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I think this motion is going to be supported today in a bipartisan fashion. It has been a great tragedy for the people of Taiwan to have suffered such a mammoth earthquake, and the fact that it occurred right in the middle of the island and then spread to each end of the island has been quite sad and tragic for so many people. To have so many people now killed and so many missing and injured is just dreadful, and it is so much more tangible to those of us who visited Taiwan recently and know what a kind, gentle and intelligent race the Taiwanese are and how much they are suffering. Therefore, I commend this motion of Senator Calvert's to the Senate to make sure that we do express our thoughts and good wishes to the people of Taiwan.

—by leave—I join with Senator Knowles and, indeed, with all the senators and members of the Australian parliament in expressing commiserations to the people of Taiwan on the terrible tragedy that they have suffered in the past few days, a tragedy which was compounded by second and third major earthquakes yesterday. There are now over 2,000 people dead and over some 100,000 people homeless. It is much suffering and many individual people are hurt.

speech.para: But out of destruction and misery comes something good. One of the very first offers of assistance received by the people of Taiwan was from mainland China. Senators would know that the relationship between Taiwan and China has been strained in recent months but, when this tragedy struck, that bad relationship was put to one side with offers of assistance. Offers have come from other nations of the world, and we would hope that the misery that the people of Taiwan are currently suffering will be short lived.

debateinfo.title: PETROLEUM RETAIL MARKETING SITES AMENDMENT REGULATIONS

talk.start.para: —I move business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1:

speech.para: That the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 2), as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No. 163 and made under the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980, be disallowed.

The petroleum retailing industry is currently regulated by the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980, known as the franchise act, and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980, commonly known as the sites act. The franchise act governs the contractual relationship between the oil majors and site operators. It largely applies to franchised sites and has no real impact on sites which are operated on a commission agency basis—that is, where the site operator receives a set amount per litre of fuel sold. I would describe that typically as a factory outlet.

The sites act regulates the number of retail sites that each of the four major oil companies are permitted to directly operate. It was introduced in 1981 with a view to ensuring that the major oil companies did not control all retail outlets. The number of sites that each company can own is as follows: BP, 102; Shell, 114; Caltex, 136; and Mobil, 87. I understand that those figures now equate to approximately five per cent of the total number of retail sites. BP's original quota of sites was 87, but they obtained a temporary increase of 15 additional sites earlier this year. It should be noted that sites which are operated on a commission agency basis for fuel and a franchise operation for the shop are regarded as being directly operated under the sites act. This is becoming the oil companies' preferred method of operation, as I understand it.

The amending regulation which is the subject of this disallowance—Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 2)—temporarily increases BP's quota of sites from 102 to 212 for the period 1 June 1999 to 30 September 1999, almost a doubling. This temporary increase was presumably negotiated with the minister with the expectation that the sites act would be repealed in view of government policy or at least dealt with by 30 September 1999.

The government's policy is that the franchise act and the sites act will be repealed and replaced by the Oilcode. The Oilcode is a code of conduct setting out a number of matters which will regulate the relationship between site operators and oil companies. It is much more comprehensive than the franchise act and will be given the force of law under part IVB of the Trade Practices Act 1974. Subsequent to the repeal of the sites act, there was to be no limitation on the number of sites that the oil companies could directly operate.

My understanding as to why it is suggested that this regulation is necessary is as follows. The usual term of a franchise agreement between an oil company and a site operator is nine years, which may or may not be comprised of a three-year initial term and two three-year options. The franchise act commenced in 1981. The consequence is that a number of BP's franchised sites are coming up for renewal now at the end of the second nine-year period—that is, the first agreement would have run from 1981 to 1989 and the second agreement from 1989 to 1998. I understand that many of the franchise agreements expired before the end of 1998. BP has held off re-franchising its franchise sites because it wishes to convert almost all of its 300 company owned sites to commission agency sites on fuel and franchise sites on shop arrangements but cannot do so until the sites act is repealed.

I have moved this disallowance motion today for two reasons. The first relates to the substantive issues of deregulation and competition and how that can be best achieved in this industry. The second relates broadly to the method of implementation of government policy and the right of the parliament—in this case the Senate—to deal with government policy as it is presented in legislation and for the decisions of the Senate not to be pre-empted by executive government action. The Democrats' views as to competition in the petroleum industry are set out in our minority report of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. That committee was held to review the Petroleum Retail Legislation Repeal Bill 1998 . I would also draw the attention of the Senate to our supplementary report to the joint select committee inquiry into the retailing sector which is relevant to the extent that it identifies the approach we take on competition issues.

The Australian Democrats are concerned about vertical integration in the petroleum industry—that is, the manner in which the majors control everything from extraction to refining to wholesaling and retailing. The potential for these companies to further vertically integrate their operations by giving them a greater ability to directly control the pump price is contrary, in our view, to the promotion of competition at the retail level. We would like to see an increase in the level of independent wholesale and retail activity and wholesale and retail competition. We do not believe this is achieved if oil companies are increasingly controlling retailing directly to more and more consumers. In our view, competition is promoted by separating rather than integrating the manufacturing, wholesaling and retailing sectors of the industry.

This amending regulation, which allows BP to increase the number of sites over which it has price control, is in direct conflict with our belief as to the direction in which the industry should be heading. It appears that our views are, to a greater or lesser extent, in accord with the views of government members of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. The conclusion which my colleague Senator Woodley reached as a member of that committee was that the Oilcode could be implemented at the same time as the franchise act is repealed, and that is two of the legs of the government's policy.

But the third leg is that the committee felt that the sites act should remain in place for another two years while a wholesale access regime is implemented. The sites act should only then be repealed if it appeared to a Senate inquiry that that access regime is giving rise to healthy competition at the wholesale and retail levels. This conclusion and recommendation was in very similar terms to the recommendation of the government members of the committee, who also recommended retention of the sites act for two years. Those members did not recommend immediate repeal of the sites act, nor did they recommend any type of suspension of the operation of that act.

I understand that the member for Hunter, the shadow minister for small business, Mr Joel Fitzgibbon, has introduced a bill into the House of Representatives that will allow franchisees to buy up to 50 per cent of their fuel requirements from sources other than their franchisor. The Australian Democrats support the basis of that type of reform. I understand that that bill has as its basis a desire to promote competition at the wholesale level, which has to be a commendable objective. The more service stations purchasing fuel at the terminal gate, the greater competition will be in that market. We support any measures that will improve competition at the wholesale level. We support any measures that will improve competition at the retail level. This regulation has the opposite effect because it allows oil companies to directly control the retail fuel price and allows them to do so before the proposed reforms have been put in place.

The other basis for this motion is a belief that this amending regulation pre-empts a decision by the Senate on the government's policy to repeal the sites act. The government announced this policy some time ago and the Petroleum Retail Legislation Repeal Bill 1998 is currently awaiting debate in the Senate. The Australian Democrats have not sought to delay the bringing on of that legislation. I must at this juncture recognise that both the Labor Party and the government have been in productive talks with us about that legislation. We are happy to deal with that legislation as soon as it is brought on. In fact, we have been happy to deal with that legislation since the tabling of the Senate committee report into that bill in June, some three months ago.

The introduction of the government's petroleum deregulation policy has been delayed for a number of reasons, one of which has been the slow process on gaining agreement to the new Oilcode. That delay is unfortunate, but no person, as I understand it, has deliberately delayed the implementation of the policy so as to adversely affect BP. If BP is adversely affected by that delay, then it is as a result of the structure of BP's operations and as a result of their own executive decisions. It is not a result of any special or disadvantageous treatment. All major oil companies are subject to the same industry regulation and the same acts. I emphasise that if BP is somehow shut out of the reform process it will not be as a result of special adverse regulatory treatment; it will be as a result of the way in which BP has structured its decisions.

I understand that both Caltex and Mobil faced a similar situation to BP—that is, a large number of their franchise agreements were expiring last year. However, Caltex and Mobil simply pursued the normal course and proceeded to re-franchise those sites. They did not hold off entering into new franchise agreements in anticipation of the change in the regulatory regime. To that extent, if we do not disallow this regulation BP will be given a special advantage, at least relative to Caltex and Mobil. The Australian Democrats are not looking to focus on BP; we are forced to do so by the fact that this regulation is before us. In fact, we wish to publicly record that we commend BP Australia as a company on its progress in producing cleaner fuels and on other industry decisions it has taken to be a productive member of the corporate community.

We are looking to ensure that all the major oil companies are, however, bound by the same rules. The problem here is that the Senate has not agreed to the deregulation of the industry and the repeal of the sites act. It might well do so. But until that legislation is before us, we cannot make that judgment. Unfortunately, BP is pursuing a strategy on the basis of an assumption that the government's policy is law and will become law. That is not the case, and early indications, in the form of the Senate committee's report, are that the sites act will not be repealed.

The government seem to be saying that because the Senate has not yet had a chance to debate this legislation in the interim they will just pass a regulation to allow BP to restructure its operations in anticipation of the passage of the repeal legislation. That is not good government. It is not good policy. If a piece of legislation has a high priority for the government or for industry, then the government have an obligation to bring it to the Senate so a decision can be made on it. I will repeat to the minister publicly what I have said privately: the Australian Democrats are happy to consider that legislation next week if the government so desire.

I would like to raise one further point. This regulation expires on 30 September 1999. If we were to agree to it and I were to withdraw this disallowance motion or if the motion were defeated, what would happen then? There is almost no chance that the sites act will be repealed by 30 September 1999 or even that an acceptable reform package will be agreed to. I am advised that the industry is still in disagreement as to the recommendations of the Senate committee and as to the further discussions had between members of the political parties and the industry. That presumably means that another regulation which continues to permit BP to maintain more than its original quota of sites will need to be gazetted from 1 October to whenever. And how long would we have to continue to do that? So, once again, the purpose of denying the regulation would be to put pressure on both the industry and the government to bring that legislation before us so that the parliament can make its decision on a government policy and on the Senate committee recommendations.

talk.start.para: —I rise on behalf of the opposition, particularly my colleague the shadow minister for small business, Joel Fitzgibbon, to indicate our support for this motion to disallow the amendments to the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 2), as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No. 163 and made under the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980. We support the motion to disallow. The reasons given by Senator Murray, who has moved the motion on behalf of the Democrats, we believe are sound and compelling. We will strongly support this motion of disallowance.

speech.para: I will make some general remarks about the policy of the petroleum industry on the marketing and retail side in Australia. Over the last three years the opposition has been very patient and given the government plenty of time to negotiate an outcome between the manufacturers, the petroleum companies, the franchisees and the retailers over a new Oilcode that, as Senator Murray said, would be mandated under the Trade Practices Act and enforceable, to reach an agreement with both sides as to how the industry should operate to the advantage of the petroleum companies, the retailers and, of course, the Australian consumers.

I, as a former small business minister, know how difficult it is to negotiate such an outcome with the interest groups that I have just mentioned. During the period of 1993 to 1996, when I was a minister, I had endless discussions, bilaterally, trilaterally and individually, with those groups to try to reach an agreement on a new Oilcode. We left office before that had been reached but, because we understood the difficulty of trying to reach an agreement, the opposition has been very cautious in criticising the government over its reaching an agreement. We have encouraged the government. We have supported the government at the various Senate committees and, in particular, the committee that dealt with the legislation chaired by Senator Crane. I think we worked on all sides very cooperatively in a bipartisan and tripartisan way to reach an outcome on the legislation that this Senate could support and that the industry could live with so that we can get on with it. I thought Senator Crane bent over backwards to be cooperative, and I am sure he would acknowledge the cooperation from our side as well in that we saw this as being in the national interest rather than an as opportunity to engage in political point scoring.

At one stage, I think earlier this year, the minister announced with great flamboyance in response to a question time dorothy dixer that he was tabling the new Oilcode. The only thing he failed to mention was that what he tabled from his department was not an Oilcode that had been agreed to by the parties; it was a draft Oilcode that the department thought was a pretty good basis and probably had 90 per cent plus agreement but it had not been signed off on. We made the point at the time that, no matter what the government tables, unless the parties agree to it, it is really no better than confetti left over after a wedding. That has been the case. The parties had not agreed.

Our patience has now basically started to run out on this government's policy. This regulation that the minister has put up really shows the failure of government policy. In a desperate move to overcome not reaching a conclusion or not being able to encourage the parties to reach a conclusion, we are now given by the government a proposition: if you do not accept these amendments to the regulation, BP will be in contravention of the act and therefore penalties may apply and action can be taken. `And we don't want that to happen,' says the government.

If the government could have seen this coming, if they had been in proper discussions with BP during 1998, they would have known, as Senator Murray pointed out, that the second nine-year term on the franchising agreements for the BP franchisees had run out during 1998 and that they would have to be negotiated. As Senator Murray quite rightly pointed out, at the end of the nine-year period other companies did negotiate extensions with their franchisees. BP took a punt and said, `We believe the sites act will be repealed.' It has not been repealed; the parliament has not agreed to it. And now they want retrospectively to be given a special deal.

How can you give BP a special deal when the other major oil companies like Caltex and Mobil—I think Shell is a bit different because it has moved into multisite franchising in a big way—complied with the law? I would have thought, in the Senate in particular, we have always argued for transparency and fairness and argued that no-one should be given individual or specific preference over a competitor in the industry. There is no doubt that this regulation, if carried, gives an advantage to BP that Caltex and Mobil have not got because they complied with the law. I find that very bad policy making, and it should always be avoided at all costs.

It is a policy failure on behalf of the government not to have seen this coming and, in their discussions with BP last year, warned them that they cannot automatically accept that the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act is going to be repealed until it has actually passed the parliament. Anybody in BP or any people interested in the industry would have seen that, in the Senate hearings into this bill to repeal the sites act, during the last six or seven months, there was no agreement reached and the majority of the Senate—I think I can speak on behalf of the Democrats on this as well as for the opposition—said that we would not repeal the sites act until there was an agreement on Oilcode. That was clear. The opposition had made that clear for two or three years, and I am sure the Democrats had made that clear. I think it is unfair for BP to now say, `We want retrospectively to have our breach of the sites act fixed by this regulation.' It is unfair to the other companies that have complied with the law.

I say to the minister that every effort has to be made by the government to encourage the parties to reach agreement on Oilcode and to make it enforceable under the Trade Practices Act. Until you get that, you will not convince the opposition to repeal the sites act. As Senator Murray and other people have said, the issue at stake here is about proper, reasonable competition and about giving retailers in the industry a chance to be competitive and run their businesses properly without being dictated to by the manufacturers.

Other people in the community have often made strong complaints about competition policy. I think the National Party have made statements elsewhere in Australia that they want competition policy abandoned. Competition policy should be upheld in this area. The problem we have is that, if you do not have a sites act or an Oilcode agreed to by the retailers, you do not have proper competition. It will be an oligopolistic industry vertically integrated from the refining end right through to the retailing end and the sale to the consumer.

In my own state and in other states, I have seen in electricity prices and electricity structures that government owned electricity companies are being privatised and broken up on the basis that you have to provide competition. The consumer has the right to be able to buy electricity from different companies that are privatised, yet the government has not yet taken head-on the issue of the vertically integrated nature of the petroleum industry. The only thing that is stopping it being totally integrated at the moment is the sites act. If you are going to remove the sites act, you have to get the Oilcode up so that retailers have some protection in the way they run their businesses. I think the remarks of Senator Murray are similar to the opposition's on this. We have been arguing this for a long time.

The opposition knows that this is always a difficult industry to deal with. The shadow minister put to the government yesterday a compromise, a proposition that we would agree not to support this disallowance if the government would agree to bring back a regulation to increase the number of sites available to petroleum companies, to allow the sites act to continue to operate for at least another two years and to have a proper review during that period by the ACCC. We believe that would have given enough flexibility to all companies. It would not just have given BP the advantage; it would also have given Caltex, Shell and Mobil access to having increased numbers of sites. Therefore, we treat the industry the same. We also guarantee that the sites act continue for another two years until the ACCC has a further review.

When the ACCC was the Trade Practices Commission, it looked at this industry on a number of occasions. Its comments are always about its concern on the vertically integrated nature of this industry. We think that its comments are pretty reasonable. That is what gives us warning that you should not start repealing the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act without having something in their place. It is clear the government has promised the petroleum companies, `We'll get rid of the sites act for you, and hopefully we might get an Oilcode.' That would be the bottom line of some elements of the government. I do not think it is the bottom line of Senator Crane.

talk.start.para: —Oh yes!

—No, it is not your bottom line, Senator Crane. But I think it is the bottom line of some elements of cabinet. I certainly agree that it is not the view of people like Senator Crane and probably my colleague Senator Boswell from the National Party who have been dealing with representatives at the retail end of the industry because they know how difficult it is and what damage would be done to a lot of small businesses in Australia if the sites act were unilaterally repealed. I have no doubt there are elements in cabinet—representing the big end of town, as we call it—who would be quite happy to repeal the sites act irrespective of whether there is an Oilcode in place.

speech.para: So my colleague Mr Joel Fitzgibbon made that offer on behalf of the opposition to the government yesterday, and the government rejected it. As a result, we said, `If you are rejecting what we think is a fair offer, we will support the disallowance motion.' I understand from what Senator Murray told me privately, and I do not think he will object to my saying this, that he was in discussions with the government along similar lines.

Why did the government reject outright negotiation on getting a settlement along the lines that I have outlined? I think Senator Murray may well have had discussions with the government along similar lines. We in the opposition—and I think the Democrats are the same—are not unbending on this. We understand there are complexities in this industry and, if you take a very black-and-white attitude to it, you will end up drowning yourself in quicksand. The complexities of this industry are well known to us all. But the government's attitude is: first, fix up one company's problems when it did not follow the law as it knew it operated; and, second, one way or the other ignore the fact that we have to get an outcome on the Oilcode.

We believe this has shown a very bad episode of government failure in policy. I mentioned before that we have given the benefit of the doubt to the government on this issue for a long time because we know how difficult it is. But they have now started to fail. I make the offer to the government on behalf of Mr Fitzgibbon that we will always be willing to have negotiations with the government on getting an outcome in the petroleum industry, but it must be an outcome in which the industry is not just handed over to the full and unfettered market power of the petroleum companies. That is something we are not going to be in.

In the end, the government has to recognise that, if we want a competitive industry, it will have to pass legislation that gives the franchisees, the retailers, a chance at a future. We recognise that economic changes mean we cannot guarantee that everyone who is a present franchisee is going to survive. We do not expect that, but we do expect there to be some goodwill in the industry so that these franchises have an opportunity. That is why Mr Fitzgibbon has moved a private member's bill, which I notice Senator Murray com mented favourably on, to allow franchisees to have an opportunity to purchase up to 50 per cent of their petrol at a wholesale price from suppliers other than their franchisor. We believe that is starting to open up the industry and to give proper, effective competition to the franchisee so that they are not absolutely beholden to an arrangement imposed on them by the power of the major oil companies.

talk.start.para: —Who is going to buy out the contracts? Who is going to compensate them—the taxpayer?

—Senator Crane knows as well as I do that no-one is talking about breaking existing contracts but, when new contracts become available, that is when new arrangements start to take effect. You do not override existing contracts.
—Go and read his bill. It is obvious.

—If you indicate that you are opposed to giving franchisees, retailers, that opportunity, then that is a position I am interested to hear the government state. I do not think there is a lot of people in the Liberal or National parties who would agree with your view on that, Senator Crane, if that is your policy view.

speech.para: This is an attempt by the opposition to recognise that small business in the petroleum industry has the right to have an effective future. We would be more than happy to have discussions with the government about that private member's bill. If the government wants to make suggestions and improvements to that bill, then my colleague Mr Fitzgibbon would be more than happy to have those discussions, as I am sure other members in the Senate would be.

It seems to us that this government really does not have a long-term plan for this industry other than to repeal the sites act and the franchise act and then let unfettered market forces take place. That will mean that in the end all the major petroleum retail outlets will be run on an agency basis, effectively directly owned and managed by the oil companies. Therefore, we will end up with a totally vertically integrated industry of three or four majors running the refining, distribution, marketing and retailing of petroleum in this country. I do not think that is good competition policy for those who tell us all the time that competition policy is what we should be about. That is not good competition policy.

Finally, I have noticed that some of the oil companies have said that, unless they get the sites act repealed, they will not reinvest in upgrading refineries in Australia. I know the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources would quite rightly take note, as we do, of some of those comments. But, again, I do not think you can write the policy on the petroleum industry based on the threat that some refineries in Australia may not be revamped, upgraded or redeveloped as they run through their normal life cycle. If that becomes the only basis of deciding petroleum policy in this country, I think we will end up with a very bad outcome. Irrespective of the sites act, I unfortunately believe that some of the existing refineries in Australia will close. As Senator Minchin would know, I suspect the one in Adelaide run by Mobil may be one of those that in the long term Mobil would say may not have a future. I hope that is not correct, but I do know that that may occur irrespective of whether the sites act is repealed.

The opposition strongly support this disallowance motion. We regret the fact that the government refused the offer which even the Democrats may have been willing to go along with—an offer to have a different regulation brought forward that would have dealt with all the companies equally. This offer would have guaranteed the sites act for another two years and a proper, independent inquiry by the ACCC to protect the industry until the industry can get—led by good leadership, we hope, by the government—a positive Oilcode in place under the auspices of the Trade Practices Act. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise on behalf of the government to indicate our opposition to this motion of disallowance relating to the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 2). I will not prolong the debate; I will just make a few points.

speech.para: I utterly reject the fatuous remarks from the opposition about government policy. Government policy on this issue has been fundamentally clear, well thought through and comprehensive, and includes a reform agenda that involves the repeal of the franchise act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act and their replacement by the insertion in the Trade Practices Act of an Oilcode. That has been our clear policy for some time. That policy has been augmented by a commitment we made at the last election that we would not proceed to repeal these acts unless there was agreement by all parties to the full package—that is, that the franchise act and the sites act would go and be replaced by the Oilcode in the Trade Practices Act. That is why the position espoused by Senator Schacht is so nonsensical. He obviously does not understand our policy when he says that all we are on about is repeal of the two acts and then it is unfettered law of the jungle. That is not the case. We believe this should operate like every other industry in Australia—under the auspices of the Trade Practices Act, with a special provision in that act regulating this industry in particular through the Oilcode. So it is a comprehensive package. We made that fundamental commitment to all parties at the time of the last election—that we would not proceed unless there was agreement among all parties to this package.

At this stage we do have agreement on the Oilcode. I think we do have agreement that the franchise act should go. But we do not, as yet, have agreement on the question of the sites act. The position is, frankly, that the companies cannot support the package if it does not include repeal of the sites act, but there are other parties who cannot support the package if it includes repeal of the sites act. That is the current impasse. But in the meantime the companies have had to plan for the future on the basis of the government having enunciated a clear policy and an intention to proceed with that. They have got to take that as a clear statement of government policy, knowing that it still has to run the gauntlet of this Senate and that agreement still needs to be reached.

But in the meantime BP in particular were reaching a point where they had to make a decision. A whole lot of their sites were coming up for renegotiation, so they had to make a commercial decision. They sought from us a temporary increase in their quota under the sites act, pending the outcome of the discussions and negotiations through which we are endeavouring to reach agreement on the full package. It seems to me to be ridiculous, and quite unfair to BP, to force them, while these negotiations are continuing, to have to refranchise all their sites for nine years and then be disadvantaged. I am happy to quote what BP said to me. They said:

This motion, if carried, will effectively put us out of the game as far as regulatory reform is concerned. We will be required to refranchise all of the sites under the old system for nine years and we will be disadvantaged vis-a-vis the other players. It also means a significant lessening of the relevance of the package if one of the four companies is excluded on the eve of some resolution.
I think they are dead right: it is ridiculous.

You talked about not wanting to disadvantage anybody. It would clearly disadvantage them if, on the eve of a potential resolution of this issue, the Senate forced BP to refranchise all those sites for nine years. That is bad public policy. That is where, frankly, the opposition and the Democrats are responsible for very bad public policy, to the distinct disadvantage of BP. If the whole thing does come unstuck, this is only a temporary increase in site quotas and BP would then have to make that commercial decision whether to refranchise or change its operation in some other way on the basis of existing law. That would be a commercial decision they would have to make. But, pending the outcome of our discussions to try to resolve this issue, it really is ludicrous to force BP, as a result of this motion being successful—as it clearly will be—to have to refranchise all those sites with the possibility that there may still be some resolution of this matter that would allow the companies to restructure their operations in ways which are efficient and better.

Reform of the petrol industry is a long saga. I have tried to act as gracefully as I can. I accept what Senator Schacht said—that attempts were made in their reign to try to reform this industry, without success. It is not easy. The parties are so far apart. We have done an enormous amount of work to try to bring the parties together. We are very close, but we are not there yet. In the meantime, it seems to me to be eminently appropriate, sensible and reasonable that this temporary increase in the quota be granted to BP, pending the outcome of those discussions, knowing that if there is no resolution they will have to refranchise those sites when the temporary increase ceases to take effect.

talk.start.para: —I rise in support of the disallowance motion in relation to the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 2).

speech.para: The Australian Democrats are concerned about wholesale and retail competition in the petroleum industry so as to ensure that both the business owners and the consumers are given a fair go. It is the belief of the Australian Democrats that the Australian petroleum market is not yet at a point where it is mature enough in its diversity of ownership to sustain a significant level of vertical integration by a small number of large companies. I make specific reference to the independent network that exists and continues to grow.

The issue of vertical integration is a very pertinent issue in regard to today's disallowance motion. As I see it, major oil companies are no longer able to derive significant income from their refining operations. As a consequence of this they are looking to play a more significant role in the wholesale and retail sector of this market. One cannot deny the fact that there are those who believe that a greater level of vertical ownership will bring about some economies of scale. However, with such economies there are also two very important consequences that need to be considered before removing the veil and opening up the opportunity for such operations. These are, in effect: inefficiencies emerging from complacency, and temptations to become the price maker instead of the price taker. These two issues alone raise a significant enough question in my mind to raise the rung of caution that one peg higher. Part of the reason that my colleague Senator Andrew Murray has moved this disallowance motion is this overshadowing issue of vertical integration and its possible negative consequences, particularly over the longer term.

I have to say that, in my experience, healthy competition in the retail marketplace of any industry ensures the best outcome for all stakeholders. In the petroleum market, a large component of this healthy competition has come as a result of the influx of independent operators over recent times. Let me be clear about this. Whatever we do with the current reform process, we must ensure that there is provision for the independents to continue to be effective participants in the retail petroleum market.

Today, however, we are dealing with BP. BP have not just been a few retail sites over the number that they are legally allowed to operate; they are operating over double their legally allowable quota. How this came about is a question that only the senators to my left can answer. I will come back to this issue in a moment.

First, I think it would be wrong of me to espouse that the petroleum industry is an industry that is without problems. In fact, there are serious problems in a whole range of facets of this industry. This is in part why the process of reform has taken as long as it has. From reading the various reports on this matter over the past 20 years, it is almost as if we are continuing a circle of parties standing desperately at odds with each other, wanting to increase their share with no regard for the other stakeholders in the market.

The current process of reform has taken a serious amount of time to get to the position that we are in today. I am not sure that it is all that far advanced from where we were 20 years ago. What I do know is that the franchise act and the sites act have played an important role in shaping the direction of this industry. It is also true that we are on the road to some positive change, and I say this with my mind's eye viewing the benefits that will be gained from the Oilcode if it is introduced. However, the Oilcode is not something that can stand alone without support to ensure that vertical integration does not occur to a greater extent than is already occurring in this industry.

Taking this into consideration, I therefore think it is wise for us to take a few moments to look at some of the specific issues that are at play here. These issues relate to the structure of the petroleum industry itself. I want to talk very briefly about the commission agency sites arrangement. The operation of petrol stations under a commission agency agreement is something that some operators in the retail segment wish to have, but at the same time there are quite a number of operators who wish not to have this. A commission agent arrangement under the existing sites act means that the number of sites that are owned by the oil company remains limited to five per cent of the total number of sites. Maybe tolerance of this practice should be shown and this figure could be slightly increased. But even if this were to occur, it would need to be done as part of the whole reform process, not at the demand of one industry operator—the manner BP has used.

Second, I want to quickly talk about the franchise agreement sites. This is a situation where the retail petrol sites are set into a franchise agreement under the franchising act of 1980. The current structure of the market has these agreements in a situation of three sets of three years, giving a franchise time frame of nine years. Considering the level of investment, particularly in this instance from the franchisee, looking at lease times significantly less than this would mean greater changes to contractual arrangements under which the agreement is reached. This, however, does not mean that this form of operation should be disregarded. Franchising remains an effective and preferred means of operation for many retailers.

On the issue of terminal gate access, ultimately effective terminal gate access is the means by which competition at a wholesale level can be guaranteed. Unfortunately, with lagging margins in the refining process, oil companies have very much shied away from making terminal gate access effective. If it is to be what it really needs to be, then there ought to be freedom for retail operators under franchise agreements or otherwise to procure some significant proportion of their fuel from the lowest bidder. Interestingly, I think very few operators would actually exercise this right to buy fuel from other suppliers, but it would put oil companies on notice that they are not the only stakeholders in this industry. This brings me back to BP's conduct of late.

Since 21 September of last year BP have been failing to renew a significant number of their franchises, and hence this has placed the operators of these sites in limbo as to what the future will hold. This practice has meant that the site numbers that BP control have increased without regulatory concession—essentially, it was done illegally. I find it interesting that other oil companies appear to have been refranchising their sites, as they are required to do under the act—that was until BP's actions became clear. Those actions second-guess the reform process and seek to obtain commercial benefit from this anticipation of change without regard to the current laws.

I doubt that there will be agreement in the next few days on what the structure of the market will be, but the structure of the market is a side issue. A company operating outside of a parliamentary act and then expecting the parliament to overlook this operation by giving special regulatory concession is the issue. Having said that, I am not oblivious to the need for commercial businesses to maximise their opportunities in their respective markets. Yet I think that it is quite clear that BP would have to have refranchised these sites in any case as a result of there being no foreseeable agreement. Hence BP's commercial disadvantage argument holds no real weight in my mind. What does hold weight is the fact that the parliament sets in place laws and these laws must be adhered to.

The Australian Democrats have made their position quite clear in the minority report of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee into the Petroleum Retail Legislation Repeal Bill 1998 . We will not support moves in markets that foster greater levels of vertical integration. As I said earlier, this situation simply does not inspire a healthy, competitive environment for all of the stakeholders concerned.

Not being privy to the conversations that happened between the minister and BP repre sentatives, I do not know what has been promised or what deals have been done. What I am sure of is that, whatever deal was made, it was one that was inappropriate for the government to have made. If BP see themselves in a position of commercial disadvantage, then they need to look to the government and specifically to the minister as a place to vent their anger and frustration. The minister had no right to put this issue on the table for the Senate and then expect the Senate to swallow it without question.

The Australian Democrats' views are well known to all stakeholders that have taken the time to listen to what we have said. The government knew what our views were and it is very arrogant of them to have made the assumption that we should have simply accepted their regulation. So the message for the government from the Australian Democrats is quite clear: the laws are in place and they are there to be followed until such time as they are repealed.

If BP want to operate outside of these rules so as to obtain a commercial advantage, then they will suffer the consequences of such actions. I am yet to be convinced that BP should be offered special consideration against other oil companies. I feel that, if we are to give concessions to BP, then they must also be given to all of the oil companies. If we do this, then we ignore standards that are set in the sites act. In my view that is not appropriate, particularly given that the Senate is still deciding what the future of the sites act will be. In closing, I make my support clear for the disallowance of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 2).

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Democrats' disallowance motion. Deregulation in the petroleum industry, particularly with the ability of the large companies to have vertical integration, is having a very savage impact on the small percentage of privately owned service stations, as well as on the company agents and the franchise sites. I do not believe it is in the public interest for the industry to be deregulated in such a way that the larger fuel companies can, by specific marketing policies, disadvantage this small percentage of freehold service station owners.

speech.para: In Brisbane it is not uncommon to go through a series of service stations and find a fuel price there in the range of 62.5c. Just a few months ago, while in Brisbane, I called in and refuelled a vehicle in the morning at a service station at Browns Plains. I spent the day driving around and came back that afternoon to refuel at the same service station, only to find that the price then was in excess of 69c—quite a substantial change from the morning price of 62.9c. I inquired of the manager of the service station as to why this was the case. He was instructed to travel around his area of a morning, find out what the lowest price was in the area and report back to the oil company. They then informed him as to what price to put on his pumps.

Although the disallowance motion is directed primarily at BP, I believe that there are actions within this industry that go beyond what we are also discussing here today. An independent owner who purchases his fuel, if the oil company does not afford him a rebate, is forced to sell his fuel at a margin at which he can survive. So we have a situation where we have one part of the industry that has the ability, through being either an oil company franchise or an oil company site, to fluctuate their price on a daily basis to be able to maximise their market while we have somebody in the same industry who does not have the ability to do that. I believe that the sites act should be retained, but there definitely needs to be an in-depth study, in continuance of the Senate one that has been identified by Senator Murray, that will focus on the actual day-to-day operations of the service stations.

An analogy would be to look at the present situation in the retail grocery market. We have predatory pricing in that industry in an attempt to remove the independent operators. I believe that there are similarities there with the petroleum industry. As I said earlier, I do not believe that it is in the public interest to have the deregulation of these industries based on the fact that deregulation will provide to the consumer a better price. I do not believe this has been the case in the petroleum industry. It certainly has not been the case in the grocery retail market. Therefore, I indicate the support of Pauline Hanson's One Nation for the disallowance motion.

talk.start.para: —In concluding the debate, I want to thank the participants. What has come through very clearly here is a statement again by speakers as to just how appallingly uncompetitive and restrictive many of the practices in the oil industry are and how much we need some real and proper reform here to reintroduce true competition and true protection on a fair basis for independent wholesalers and retailers in the industry.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the following bills, allowing them to be considered during this period of sittings:
Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999
Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999.
Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I will continue my remarks from yesterday on the Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 . Fraudulent providers are currently still operating. Due to the Howard government's ineptness, shonky operators are still running some of the homes, which further exacerbates the vulnerability of the elderly. The Tasmanian situation is particularly horrendous, due to the ill-fated coalescence proposal that will represent a cut of over $22 million in seven years. This will rip the heart out of our regional economy, naturally translating into reduced choices and comfort for the generation that carries the scars of defending the nation.

speech.para: The proven therapeutic value of residing in a local community will be further limited, as the possibility of units closing becomes a reality; and the elderly will be moved like cattle as this dollar-driven government continues with its ideological agenda. Thus the option of the elderly being cared for by the children and grandchildren of past and present friends may only exist for the few, and their treasured memories—that are often cued by the sight of familiar surroundings—may disappear more readily than otherwise.

We have a family friend, a lady in her late 80s, who has lived in her community all her life. She is a typical example of somebody who has no family close by and no means of transport. If she had to move from that community, she would be devastated. She needs to live where she is able to be visited by friends and friends' children, people she has known all her life. At this stage, fortunately, that is not going to happen; but, if in future it does, I suspect that her lifespan will be much shorter. She is in good health at present, but I know that for her family it is a concern that she may eventually have to move away from that community, because the nursing home there is a very small one.

An assessment of nursing homes in Tasmania found that a number of homes fell short of meeting some of the requirements for adequate care of the elderly. This was in most cases due to shortages of funds needed for staff and training or capital works. It therefore seems ironical that the bill contains no real remedies to fix the shortfall in capital funding, as the accommodation charges fall short of the funds needed. Additionally, there is no requirement for providers to spend the money raised by the accommodation charge on capital works. As in any industry, there will be those that simply pocket the money without the upgrades needed being started. This will become specifically relevant as the government's plans for accreditation are exerted.

Accreditation is often a useful way of increasing standards and universality of care. However, this can only be achieved if ad equate funding is given to enable the standards to be met. Remember that the cost of accreditation in Tasmania will range from $40,000 to $120,000 per annum. Thus this policy has many obvious flaws that will inevitably translate into increased hardship, reduced security and a real reduction in care received, as sound policy and realistic capital grants are compromised by the government's cynical, penny-pinching agenda. Remember that this is happening in the International Year of Older Persons. Heaven help them when this year is over.

The resident classification scale revised on 1 November 1998 will also cause some problems, as in the case of St. Mark's Home in Deloraine. These changes in the criteria essentially rest on whether a patient has to have their tablets placed in their mouth or in their hand, and will result in a loss of subsidies of up to $84,000—according to a fax I received from St Mark's Home. It is important to remember that the quality of life for the elderly in homes directly relates to the experience of life in many institutions—as this short statement eloquently shows:
Others are in charge of me now.
I have no private place of my own.
I do not belong here.
I share my bedroom with people I would not have in my own home.
There are too many people here in this nursing home. I don't feel comfortable here. I mean, where else would you live where people just come and barge in?

This statement is contained in volume 36 of the Lincoln Papers in Gerontology , in an article called The Articulate Resident's Perspective on Nursing Home Life , which paints a picture that is in stark contrast to the happy snaps contained in the department's `Home & Residence Choices for Older People'. After peering into the happy snaps created by the department, one would be excused for signing up straight away and neglecting to think that, for many of the elderly, nursing homes can be places of isolation and shame.

There is nothing in the government's policy that will enrich anyone's life; rather, the Tasmanian experience will create a reduction in choice of location and residence and an increasing insecurity in staff—an insecurity that invariably translates into compromised service. The Tasmanian industry does not need greater proportional funding because of greed or ineptness; rather, it is a natural consequence of regional economies of scale and an island status. This is recognised by the Productivity Commission but was rejected by the government, who hid the report and ignored many parts that they did not like.

Again I need to repeat the figures which I alluded to previously in the chamber and which clearly illustrate the unique nature of Tasmania's position as a regional industry.
