—Senator Carr, if that reflection on the member has been made, I would seek that you withdraw it.
—I am hurt.

—I am glad to see that the senator is so hurt by these suggestions. I do not think that he did buy the seat—if I might confirm that. I understand that his father was able to distribute considerable sums—
—If that reflection is there, I ask you to withdraw it.
—Whatever you wish, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Are you withdrawing it?
—I am withdrawing whatever you have asked me to withdraw.
—I rise on a point of order. That is a qualified withdrawal. It is a serious accusation that Senator Carr is making against the McGauran family.
—On the point of order, I did ask Senator Carr, if that was the reflection, to withdraw it unconditionally. Will you withdraw unconditionally, Senator Carr?
—I have already done that, Mr Acting Deputy President. Can I suggest that the National Party—
—I rise on a point of order. He is playing ducks and drakes. I am sure that you would agree with me on the point of order.
—You can resume your seat, Senator. Senator Carr, you can withdraw unconditionally.
—I have withdrawn unconditionally.
—Thank you. You may proceed.

—Point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Again, I am very sensitive about this and therefore I want an unconditional withdrawal. He said, `I have withdrawn unconditionally.' I would ask him to withdraw unconditionally. He has not, to this point.
—I am satisfied that there has been an unconditional withdrawal of any reflection on your obtaining a place in this honourable chamber. Senator Carr, proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The National Party have yet to learn some of these basic lessons. The fact remains that they are unable to effectively represent rural and regional communities and have been demonstrated to have lost the confidence of rural and regional Australia. It is quite apparent that, given the responses here, they have still to learn these basic lessons. So not only is it Mr John Howard and Mr Jeff Kennett that have failed to appreciate this matter; it is quite apparent that Senator McGauran has yet to appreciate the seriousness of the political crisis that is facing the National Party.

speech.para: It is important to appreciate that the Howard government policies have inflicted huge social damage upon this country. In simple terms, over the last three years we have seen the removal from the states of some $1½ billion in federal funding. We have seen community infrastructure decline dramatically as a direct result of the huge cuts that have occurred, for instance, in education. We have seen TAFE colleges in provincial cities and metropolitan areas financially squeezed almost to the point of extinction. We have seen serious funding shortfalls in TAFE in Ballarat, Bendigo and at Wodonga. We have seen huge losses in Gippsland. Last December the Northern Metropolitan College of TAFE were down to a couple of days of operating monies as a result of serious financial shortfalls. They were on the verge of bankruptcy as a direct result of the savage cuts to those institutions.

Regional universities—at Ballarat, for instance—which have traditionally been major contributors to regional communities, have faced funding cuts which have almost driven them out of existence. We have seen school class sizes increase, we have seen special needs teachers removed and we have seen a whole series of actions whereby the Commonwealth has embarked upon policies which have undermined the capacity of ordinary Australians to have access to quality services. In rural communities that is particularly the case.

We have seen our national health system undermined as a result of the chaos inflicted by this government. We have seen an attempt to impose an Americanised private health sector model. We have seen state governments privatise hospitals. In Victoria we have seen them undertake actions—sometimes in a most corrupt manner—which I am sure only a judicial inquiry in Victoria will fully reveal. There have been actions with regard to the Crown Casino which, in due course, will come to light. We have seen a climate of fear and intimidation in Victoria to the point where people are not prepared to come forward but, through the secrecy of the ballot box, they have been saying, `That's not good enough,' and the `mates only' policy is coming to an end. I have absolutely no doubt that when there is a proper judicial process instrument in Victoria it will get to the bottom of these issues and demonstrate that corruption has been endemic in Victoria under the Liberals. With regard to telecommunications there has been a massive loss in services as a result of the privatisation of Telstra. We have seen huge job losses inflicted disproportionately on rural and regional Victoria.

In the last election the coalition was able to secure only 41 per cent of the primary vote compared to Labor's 46 per cent of the vote—or 51 per cent on a two-party preferred basis. This reflects the Victorian result at the federal election last October. In fact, if the truth be known, Senator Richard Alston was a campaign director for the Liberal Party in that election, and the votes were a bit better federally for Labor. The Labor Party was able to secure 53.5 per cent of the vote—a swing of about 3½ per cent. This is despite the fact that there was a demonstrable abuse of the caretaker conventions by the national Liberal government when Senator Alston and Senator Hill used their administrative discretion to abuse the grants that were being administered through the Federation Fund cultural and heritage projects—

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I again draw your attention to the fact that Senator Carr is making unpalatable reflections on the members of this Senate, Senator Alston and Sena tor Hill. He knows full well that he is not allowed to do that. You know full well that he is not allowed to do that. I ask you to draw his attention to that standing order.
—Senator Carr, I think it would be wise if you did not cast any reflections on members in this place. I think you sailed very close to the wind on the last occasion.

—Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think that what we have here is a pattern of behaviour of secrecy and complicity within this government to abuse their privileges—and that is what the administration of public office is in this country, to take advantage of their situations by various means and to develop a secret state which highlights an arrogant and uncaring attitude towards the people of this country. It is an arrogance which presumes that people will not protest too loudly, that they will accept what is dished out to them, no matter what the abuse.

speech.para: It is quite apparent that that is not the case. It is quite apparent that, as far as most people are concerned, arrogance is no substitute for real leadership in politics—that being able to bully and buy people only gets you so far. It appears that the policies of confrontation that have been pursued by this government will be rejected. Policies such as the use of dogs and thugs in balaclavas will be rejected. A government will be rejected if it assumes that, instead of working with the community and bringing the community forward with issues, it can impose solutions. We have seen the Victorian government rejected because of its policies of `the mates come first'. We have seen a government demonstrate arrogance, contempt and a capacity to misuse the public purse in a manner which is unparalleled in the Commonwealth's history. It uses antics and sideshows as a substitute for real policies to improve the living conditions of ordinary Australians.

This is a government which has demonstrated a capacity to behave just like its cousins in Canberra. In my judgment, it is only a matter of time before the actions of this government in Victoria with regard to the building of monuments, and its corrupt behaviour with regard to the casino and its privatisation and tendering processes, will be exposed for this country to see. The sorts of actions that we have seen with regard to Hudson Conway and Penthouse Pete will undoubtedly come to the point where all will be revealed.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. That reflection on another member of the lower house is against standing orders. This is the third time that I have asked you to pull the speaker up. He continues to defy your orders. I ask you to ask him either to sit down and not proceed with his speech or to withdraw.

—In response to Senator Boswell's point of order, Senator Carr, you should refer to members by their proper title and you should not make reflections on people in other places. As I warned you on the last occasion, you are sailing very close to the wind. The Clerk and I have discussed this and we advise you to—
—We advise you to mend your ways.
—No, do not put words into my mouth, Senator Boswell. We advise you, Senator Carr, to be careful and guarded in the way in which you address members in other places.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on that point of order: as Senator Boswell stated, we are requesting a withdrawal of the reflection.
—What reflection?

—There was a serious reflection in relation to corruption and with regard to calling the member for Flinders by some sort of cheapjack nickname. We would ask you to withdraw that and address the member for Flinders as he is entitled to be addressed. More than that, you were stringing words together, previous to that, in relation to matters of corruption. It does not surprise me that Senator Carr would do that, but it is out of order.

—On that point of order, Senator McGauran, it is not a matter for withdrawal. However, as I have pointed out to Senator Carr, he should refer to members in other places by their correct and appropriate titles. I draw your attention to that, once again, Senator Carr.
—The whole question that arises from this election—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on that point of order: I am not clear on your ruling and ask for your indulgence. Are you asking him to withdraw?
—No, I am not asking him to withdraw.

—This election result is much more than a protest vote. It cannot be dismissed in such a cavalier manner. This is a fundamental rejection of the ideologically driven, uncaring and arrogant attitudes of the government, which have demonstrated that they are prepared to ride roughshod over the concerns of ordinary Australians. Ordinary Australians demand much more from government. (Time expired)

—Unlike Senator Carr, I am proud to be a Victorian and to represent Victoria in this Senate. I am also proud to be a constituent of the Kennett government—living in Victoria as I do—and a member of the Howard government team here in Canberra. Senator Carr referred to a pattern of behaviour and I might refer him back to what was the Labor pattern of behaviour both in his own federal government, culminating in Mr Keating's prime ministership, and in the Cain-Kirner government, to which Senator Carr, I believe, was an adviser. The pattern of behaviour that existed there was to bring an economy to its knees both in the state government, culminating in the election of 1992, and in the federal government, culminating in the defeat of Labor after 13 years of mismanagement of the economy. So I would suggest that he studies his own tribal patterns of behaviour very carefully before he starts to comment on those of other parties.

speech.para: If we look at some of the election policies that Mr Bracks brought forward during the recent state election, I believe that they bear no relation to any of the consistent and sensible economic policies brought forward by Prime Minister Howard. Look at such election policies as buying back Waverley football ground, bringing back 100 tram conductors and initiating pooled development funds for the country—which, to me, have sinister overtones of the Victorian Economic Development Commission of the nineties—and look at the quality of the proposed ALP frontbench, which was described in today's Sun-Herald as being `very thin and green'.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It says in the article, Senator Carr, that your team does not have the capacity to rule Victoria.

speech.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Like many of your representatives in the Senate, Senator Carr, of the 18 members of shadow cabinet, seven are former teachers and lecturers. While I have nothing against teachers, being a former teacher myself, I do have a problem with people who are elected to run the country who have no experience whatever of the private sector, and no business experience. Only two of those 18 members have run a business or held a senior executive position. That means that half of them have been union or party officials, and there are two more who were Kirner advisers. The phrase is used: `a slew of union and party officials, a couple of lawyers and just one or two from business'. That gives us no confidence whatever in the capacity of the Bracks frontbench to run Victoria.

speech.para: Victoria—and I am going to deal with it from an agricultural and educational point of view—has strong competitive advantages, as we all know. It has a fertile and productive agricultural base, a sophisticated manufacturing sector, a highly educated and skilled work force, excellent social and physical infrastructure and a mature political system. In agriculture alone, regional Victoria's productivity has increased significantly in the 1990s and the federal government has assisted in this.

Across the state in both urban and rural areas employment has grown in all major service industries, especially in trade and industries associated with tourism; and unemployment has fallen from 12.3 per cent five years ago to 7.5 per cent today. The agriculture and food industries in Victoria play a critical role in the economy, and the strong economic framework which has been provided by the coalition government in Canberra has assisted in that. You have low interest rates, you have low inflation and you have all the benefits of strong economic management associated with that.

The Kennett government established the Food Victoria initiative to work with the agrifood industry to identify and remove impediments to growth. As a result, the value of exports of agricultural commodities and processed food exports from Victoria is now around $4 billion per annum. That represents 35 per cent of the state's export earnings. Food exports have risen 79 per cent in the five years to 1997.

The Kennett government, by its strong economic management and the reduction of debt, has attracted food industry investment in excess of $1.7 billion. It has actively supported export strategies. It has established world class food industry infrastructure. It has funded research and development, and the Growing Horizons agricultural initiative launched this year provided $12.4 million in the first year, and that was a 32 per cent increase in the state's agricultural R&D projects. The Commonwealth government also assists R&D by providing matching dollars to the 15 research and development corporations that are in the agriculture portfolio and many of them have ongoing projects in Victoria. There is a food industry advisory committee in Victoria with industry leaders, and that is the framework that brings together industry and government.

The dairy industry in Victoria is meeting all of these challenges and Victoria dominates the Australian dairy industry, producing over 60 per cent of the milk, 75 per cent of manufactured dairy products and over 85 per cent of exported dairy products. The Victorian dairy industry is internationally competitive. It provides at wholesale level the state's largest agricultural income.

talk.start.para: —Are you still going to vote for deregulation in Victoria?

—Yes, deregulation will happen, Senator Schacht. The Victorian dairy industry earns in excess of $800 million in annual exports. Dairy products represent the largest single component of the Victorian food industry. Earlier this year I was delighted to open a very large—

speech.para: Senator Boswell interjecting—
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Troeth, please resume your seat for a moment. If you people want to participate in the debate, do so later. Senator Troeth is entitled to be heard.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I recently had the pleasure of opening a magnificent new Bonlac plant at Cobden. Bonlac has grown to be one of the most significant dairy product manufacturers in Australia and that plant is a fine example of a $20 million investment in regional Victoria based on innovative technology and marketing and world class environmental management systems. That whole Cobden region in Western Victoria is benefiting directly through more jobs and an increased demand for services which would have been provided by the Kennett government. That plant represents a real opportunity for the region to tap into the lucrative export market in high value dairy products. That particular example is exemplified by all of the agricultural markets and projects presently going on in rural Victoria.

speech.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There are other agricultural based industries—

speech.para: Senator McGauran interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Troeth, you were correct in resuming your seat. I was about to call these people to order. Senator Schacht and Senator McGauran, if you want to have a debate, come into the debate at the end. I cannot hear Senator Troeth because of the intervention by you people across the chamber. I am entitled to hear Senator Troeth and, if you want to put your names on the speakers list, I am sure we would welcome it later on.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. With respect, I was not interjecting.
—I did not say you were interjecting.
—Thank you. I was just having a side conversation with Senator McGauran about the future of Gippsland.
—Go down the back and have that, if you want to have a side conversation. We are entitled to hear Senator Troeth.

—I was endeavouring to tell the Senate about the success of the dairy industry and the magnificent opportunities in front of it. Not only that, but Victoria is the major state for stone fruit production. It also produces 70 per cent of Australia's processed peaches and apricots.
—How did they vote in Swan Hill? You just fell over the line.

—It is booming, Senator Schacht. It also produces 34 per cent of the dessert stone fruit. That is a booming industry. The wine industry is another growth industry and, again, that has been aided by the economic framework provided by the federal government. Again, the asparagus industry is—

speech.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht and Senator Carr, refrain from speaking whilst the honourable senator is on her feet, please.
—So we have several booming agricultural industries in Victoria.

speech.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Why don't you ask him, Senator Schacht?
—Senator Schacht, you have been invited to put your name on the list, if you desire.
—Senator Schacht, that is enough, thank you.
—Senator McGauran, I think we will be better if we proceed with Senator Troeth.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Both federal and state governments believe very strongly in farmer education. Again, Farmsmart, which is provided at the state level, is a joint initiative between the government and the VFF to assist farmers to improve their skills in overall farm business management. FarmBiz is provided through joint Commonwealth-state funding and again is an overall initiative to improve farmer education, and that is a community service which is provided in Victoria. Again, Landcare in Victoria has over 850 groups and that is helped by the Commonwealth government with NHT funding.

speech.para: I could go on to give you many other examples of the sorts of agricultural opportunities which are opening up in Victoria. But both federal and state Liberal coalition governments believe in providing the economic opportunity for both individuals and businesses to achieve their potential. The part that rural and regional communities must play in this is to look for areas in which their region has comparative strengths which can support existing businesses to grow, to create sustainable employment opportunities and to attract investment from both established and new industries.

All this involves change. It has been a recognised fact of the late eighties and most of the nineties that communities are sometimes slow to accept change and to recognise the opportunities that it brings. I believe Victoria is still in the middle of accepting change, and this is why the electorate is so volatile. We saw them dispose of the Labor government in 1992. The votes have been cast against the coalition government in this election, although it is interesting to note that seven seats in Melbourne recorded a swing to the coalition.

talk.start.para: —What? Kew, Brighton, Malvern or Hawthorn?

—Try Melbourne. Melbourne, a strong Labor seat, had a 1.6 per cent swing to the coalition, Senator Schacht, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President. We are talking about creating over time a changing economic framework in which both individuals and businesses can look at their potential. The Kennett government has recognised the need to continue to listen and respond to issues raised in regional Victoria. Throughout the seven years of its government, there have been regular regional forums, and cabinet has met frequently in country Victoria. The government was listening, and it was attempting to address the concerns of its country constituents. I would like to turn to education. Following a major period of structural reform—

speech.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, as Senator Carr was allowed to be heard in silence, I would request that he at least affords me the same courtesy.
—Ignore them, Senator Troeth.
—Unfortunately, Mr Acting Deputy President, that is not always possible. I would ask you to ask Senator Carr to refrain from interjecting.

—Senator Troeth, you are being protected, but there are times when you also invite comments. I am trying to balance both of those things and to put them in the correct perspective. You will be protected in addressing this chamber.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order.
—Senator Carr, keep out of it.
—I am not challenging that ruling, but I want to be able to understand the ruling. Senator Troeth is on her feet, so you can never say that she invites interjections.
—Of course she does!

—No. She is entitled to put her case. There is no reason for the other side ever to interject. I know that is a norm in this place, it is a culture in this place, but you cannot rule that she has invited interjections.

—Senator McGauran, there is no point of order. There have been statements made during the speech of Senator Troeth where she has addressed others and then turned back to the chair to say that the remarks were through the chair. But the remarks have been directed at those on the other side and have invited comment. I am protecting Senator Troeth as she is entitled to be protected and as I would protect any speaker on either side from any party who speaks in this chamber.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I do like your remark that you are providing me with the protection that would be provided to any other senator. I am not asking for special protection. I know Senator Carr would like me to skip over some of these facts, but the fact is that, in total, the coalition is spending over $800 million more on education this year than was provided by the former Labor government in 1991-92.
—And closing schools everywhere!
—Senator Schacht, I have invited you previously, if you want to participate in the debate, to put your name on the list and then make your comments. Otherwise, listen to Senator Troeth.

—Victoria has recorded the highest student retention rate of any state, and it outperforms all other states in encouraging students to complete their schooling. The retention rate for Victorian government school students in years 10 to 12 was 73.7 per cent, 4.3 percentage points higher than the national average of 69.4 per cent. Victorian government schools have been given the thumbs up by parents following the release of the official parent opinion survey figures which were filled in by around 50,000 parents across government schools. The survey shows that 89.1 per cent of primary school parents and 82 per cent of secondary school parents are satisfied with their schools and indicates that the public has a positive perception of government education. All secondary schools are funded on the basis of one teacher to 16 students, and primary schools are funded on the basis of one teacher to 21 students. More than 11,700 primary school classes operated across the state in 1998. Of these classes, only 6.9 per cent had more than 30 students, which was down from the 1996 level of 8.2 per cent.

speech.para: Through its information technology program, the Kennett government is well on its way to achieving its aim of equipping and skilling schoolchildren with the latest in technology. There are over 100,000 computers in Victorian schools available for student use, and the computer to student ratio is one to six, the best in Australia and one of the best in the world. So much for uncaring policies! The aim is to reduce that ratio to one to five by June 2000, and teachers are also being equipped with laptop computers and being trained in IT.

talk.start.para: —How much will they cost?
—They are free.
—When the coalition government came to office in October 1992, it inherited a $670 million backlog in government school repairs and maintenance.
—That is not true.

—Senator Troeth, resume your seat. Senator Carr, Senator Schacht and Senator McGauran: Senator Troeth is entitled to be heard. Whilst you might not agree with what she says, you have your opportunity during the debate. I do understand there are interjections as part of the debate in this place, but repeated interjections are disorderly and I remind you of that. Senator Troeth has five minutes left to speak. She is entitled to be heard and, if you have something to contribute to this debate, you are entitled to participate at a later stage. Senator Carr, you have already had your opportunity. Senator McGauran and Senator Schacht, if you want an opportunity, negotiate with your whips to get some time and stand up and participate in the debate. Senator Troeth is entitled to have her say.

—Many of those schools were literally falling apart as a result of Labor neglect—and I ought to know, because I worked in them. Since then, the government has worked hard to reduce the school maintenance backlog and, by the end of the 1998-99 financial year, it was estimated to have been reduced to less than $150 million.

speech.para: The early literacy program has also been instituted in schools, placing particular emphasis on the first three years of primary school, which, as we all know, is crucial for children's learning. Victorian primary school children have among the best literacy and numeracy skills of any state in Australia and that is being tested by LAP testing.

When the coalition came to government in Victoria and also, I might add, federally, it changed the emphasis in schools from teacher bureaucracy, industrial relations and financial support being given to the ALP to what I would describe as emphasis on true learning and the development of the child's potential. Similarly, the Commonwealth is now providing choice in education so that parents can make an informed choice between either a government school—if that is what they choose—which is equipped to a very good standard or a non-government school. We saw that, under Labor's new schools policy, very little incentive was given to those groups in the community who wanted to establish their own schools through choice in religion or choice in philosophy. Now that choice is available.

Not only that, but schools at a Commonwealth level are now being funded not through the amount of money they can raise and through looking at their budget books but through looking at where their students come from. This gives a far better indication of their school's socioeconomic rating and they can be funded accordingly. At every non-government school extension and opening I have attended in Victoria over the last year while this system has been operating, principals of every persuasion have come to me and said how grateful they are to the federal government for at last providing choice in learning for their children. That is one of the most important choices any parent can make.

I would like to finish my remarks by pointing out to the Senate that Senator Carr has not always been so keen to stand up for Victoria. He made a particularly splenetic and un-Victorian submission to the inquiry on the ABC which I would like to comment on. Senator Carr, as we all know, has been a senior member of the Labor Party in Victoria for some years. He stood by during the Keating government and allowed Paul Keating to shift ABC arts and communication jobs from Melbourne to Sydney. Perhaps Senator Carr may like the right of reply at some stage to start demonstrating that.

According to his own submission to the bipartisan Victorian parliamentary committee into the ABC, 1995 was the low point of Victoria's relative ABC staffing. Senator Carr, you were in government at that time. What did you do for Victoria? Your submission stated that staffing in Victoria has risen from a low point in 1995, and that was reached in the dying years of the Keating government.

talk.start.para: —Your own minister cut the funding, Judith.
—Tell us about Radio Australia.
—Radio Australia is a—
—Order! Senator Carr! Senator Schacht!

—At the same time, your Prime Minister, Paul Keating, showed disgraceful favouritism towards the Sydney Symphony Orchestra. Did you do anything to stand up for jobs in Victoria? You are talking about uncaring and arrogant government. When you had an opportunity to influence policy, I do not know that your Prime Minister, Paul Keating, did anything for Victoria or indeed did anything for Australia. That was why he was booted out in 1996. I hope my remarks have demonstrated that the Kennett and Howard governments have adopted the best possible policy for both Victoria and Australia.

—The result of the Victorian state election last Saturday took most Victorians by surprise. Jeff Kennett said it was a protest vote. It was indeed a protest vote but not in the way he suggested. Victorians, in my view, were not just saying, `We want to give Jeff a bit of a scare.' They were saying, `We've had enough of a government and a Premier which couldn't care less about democracy, the community, decent health and education services.' They said, `We've had enough of an arrogant Premier who can never get enough power.'

speech.para: At this election, he had the hide to stop his ministers and candidates speaking out about their policies and their record. They could not even attend forums set up in local halls in their communities. This was as stupid as it was arrogant, and anyone could have told the Premier that there would be a reaction to this kind of attitude. This is not a Premier inclined to welcome criticism or advice, and I am told he keeps control of his troops just like any schoolyard bully. The Herald Sun said last Sunday that the bullying is over. They said that his graceless speech on Saturday night showed he may not be up to the job: too inflexible, too angry, too limited, and too bored. In that speech, he said:
We Victorians have lost the advantage of giving to government the opportunity to govern.

What he really meant was that his government could no longer push through legislation without any scrutiny, no longer stitch up cosy deals in secret with mates and no longer treat the parliament with contempt. I do not recall any other period in Victoria's history in which such serious conflicts of interest, contractual bungling and destruction of the cornerstones of our democracy have put good governments at such risk.

Jeff Kennett has divided Victorians into winners and losers, and it is clear who the winners are. It has been a government that has been too closely linked with the Crown Casino and Hudson Conway. The minister for planning intervention, Mr Maclellan, has made decisions which have directly benefited the cosy Hudson Conway/Crown Casino/Grand Prix group. The Grand Prix Corporation got legal immunity from damage that was done to houses in Albert Park and by formula 1 cars. Yet Ron Walker had the gall to complain about the decision of voters in Victoria last Saturday when he said that, after all he has done for the state, this was the thanks he got. The thanks the Liberal Party has got from the likes of Mr Walker are huge dollars in their coffers, as we all know.

This is a government that has also been too dependent on gambling and too unwilling to look at the enormous problems that poker machines have caused in areas which are economically vulnerable. I was astonished, I must say, to hear Steve Bracks, the opposition leader, say that he would pay for his election promises by increasing taxes on gambling. I hope that was a mistake. I hope I misheard him.

It was all the more surprising and worrying coming, as it did, just weeks after a report by the Productivity Commission which drew attention to the unhealthy link between government facilitation of gambling and the central part that gambling taxes have played in paying for government services. Do we really want to reinforce the dependence of government on gambling money? This is a really bad sign from Mr Bracks and indicates that he has not yet grasped the fact that the culture of gambling becomes an addiction not just for the punter but for the public purse, and we can and must learn to do without it.

Who can forget in Melbourne the sudden erection of hundreds of road signs directing people towards the Crown Casino? Who can forget the bus service—and no doubt it still runs—which took people directly from suburbs like Footscray to the casino; the Premier's personal endorsement of the casino; the public underwriting of the Grand Prix in a park that would cost Victorians around $100 million; the more than 1,000 trees which were cut down in Albert Park to facilitate those formula 1 cars; and the concrete barriers and the stands occupying the park for more than three months of every year? I hope Mr Bracks takes a more enlightened view of this Grand Prix Corporation's assault on a public park in Port Melbourne when and if he comes to office.

Many Victorians were fearful when Joan Kirner first introduced poker machines into Victoria. They rightly argued that they were likely to have a huge impact on people in low income areas, and that is exactly what happened. About $921 a year was gambled for every adult in Victoria. Apparently Australians are the world's heaviest gamblers, according to the Productivity Commission's report.

Both parties in Victoria say that they will cap poker machines at $27,500 and introduce advertising rules, disclosure of the odds on machines, clocks to remind punters that they have stayed too long and a restriction on ATMs at venues. But Victorians ask the question: why should we have to wait until we have an election for these kinds of sensible measures to be put in place? I look forward to whichever party is in government delivering on those promises, and more, in relation to gambling.

Victorians said last Saturday: we are frightened of the fact that we may not get a hospital bed when we are most in need. Casemix funding, introduced in Victoria some years ago, should have been an administrative tool, but it has been used to run down hospital services and to encourage hospitals to send patients home too soon. Why is it that we have patients on trolleys in corridors for days on end when wards in those same hospitals are closed? It makes no sense, and it made Victorians very angry.

Regional hospital networking has seen important hospitals close in Victoria. The Preston and Northcote Community Hospital closed like so many others. The Mildura, Moe and Traralgon hospitals closed to make way for private hospitals. Country Victorians have seen their efforts in building up their hospitals come to nothing, just real estate to be sold off to the highest bidder, although even that is debatable. We do not even know if it is the highest bidder. The Kennett government has put its cronies into positions of power in all of these networks and into the boards which run hospitals. They have turned out to be puppets of the Victorian state government, unable to speak up and unable to protect the services of the communities that they are supposed to represent.

The closure of schools and the sacking of teachers are legendary in Victoria. Mr Kennett even changed the Constitution to stop any legal action being taken against school closures. The heavy hand of economic rationalism has been felt in education much more than any other service in Victoria, and Victorians are very deeply angry at the fact that this state now spends less than any other in this country on schools and, as a result, class sizes have risen alarmingly. The vast majority of our public schools are still dependent on old decrepit portable classrooms. They are in no sense portable. Many are 25 years old and more, relics of the sudden entry of baby boomers into schools.

We have the highest percentage of students in private schools in Victoria. Senator Troeth says that is a matter of choice, but I think it is more likely that parents see how few resources there are in government schools. Those who can pay, those who have the resources to pay, will do so in order to make sure that their children have available to them good resources. I have been into many private schools, and portable classrooms are virtually unknown in these places. Principals in government schools rightly complain to me that it seems that there is an unlimited flow of dollars for capital works for neighbouring private schools where they still depend on these old structures.

The alienation of young people in our school system is a very serious problem, but any alternative schools with more suitable programs for such young people have been scrapped. We can blame the Kennett and Kemp ideology for the growing inequity in our education system, but I think we should not forget that our education system has been underfunded for a good deal longer than the time we have had coalition governments. We have the Labor Party under Whitlam to thank for giving people access to university education, but I think we can also thank them for HECS, which has started to seriously bite into notions of equity in access to tertiary education. The shrinking dollar has as much to do with Labor as it does the coalition.

The most galling and dangerous aspect of the Kennett government's reign over Victoria is the progressive demolition of accountability mechanisms which have taken years to build in that state. Ches Baragwanath, a former Victorian Auditor-General, has been a fearless watchdog over the financial doings of the coalition and Labor governments in Victoria. He was successfully nobbled by Mr Kennett two years ago. He said the other day that he shared the views of the New South Wales Auditor-General, Tony Harris, who said that changes to the Victorian Auditor-General had set the state up for a WA Inc. style corruption scandal. Mr Baragwanath said:
I've always maintained that full light is a prerequisite to good order, that corruption flourishes behind closed doors and in the dark . . .

I remind the Senate that on two occasions in this place two years ago I put amendments to legislation which would have insisted that before federal funds were spent in Victoria there would be an independent Auditor-General in place. I also remind the Senate that neither party supported those amendments at the time.

For a long time the Democrats have been warning about the lack of accountability surrounding government outsourcing and tricks being played to stop parliament and the people knowing what is going on. The Kennett government has outsourced, privatised and corporatised to the point where financial and contractual information is almost impossible to access. We have sold off in Victoria 10 times as much as other states—$28 billion worth of public transport, electricity, the TAB, research laboratories, ports, prisons, plantations, forests and the list goes on and on and on. The Kennett government has used the national competition policy introduced by the Keating government as a tool to reduce the public sector to a shadow of its former self and spent $200 million on consultants in its first two years of office. One contract worth $24 million was recently awarded without going to tender.

All of this suggests that the Victorian parliament is just not working. In fact, in many respects, that is the case. It sat for just 20 days this year. It is not working because the upper house is simply a rubber stamp for the government. I want to take the opportunity today to say to the Senate that we should be sending a very strong message to the Victorian ALP and the coalition that it is time to reform the upper house. I will be introducing amendments to this motion to do just that, and I look forward to both parties supporting those amendments.
Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Conroy interjects and says that the Democrats would be in parliament. Indeed they would. With proportional representation similar to that of the New South Wales and South Australian governments, the Democrats would have two members in the upper house as a result of the last election. Let us have a referendum in Victoria if necessary. I believe that Victorians have had enough of unaccountable government. I think it is time we offered voters the choice of an upper house which properly scrutinises government. Reform of the upper house some years ago—in fact, many years ago—would have stopped what we now find very difficult to undo. Sure, we can have royal commissions into Intergraph and into the casino scandals, but in reality the horse has already bolted. What we need is a stitch in time, an assurance that the checks and balances are in place—a watchdog over the executive of government.

speech.para: I personally would have enjoyed the sight of the all-powerful Jeff Kennett having to use good argument to persuade the upper house to support his legislation, but it is not too late for us to bring in that reform. I call on the major parties—whoever is in power and whoever has the numbers in the upper house—to commit to this. Let us do it in the first term of the new government. Let us restore democracy and decency to Victoria. I move:
Omit all words after "That", substitute:
"the Senate:
(a) notes the disturbing parallel between the uncaring and arrogant policies of the Kennett and Howard Governments which have seen a dramatic decline in the quality of services in Victoria; and

(b) calls on both the Liberal and Labor leaders in Victoria to urgently introduce legislation to reform the Victorian Upper House electoral system so it may become a true house of review and thereby act as a guard against future episodes of mismanagement, and to ensure the legislation is passed within a year".

talk.start.para: —I cannot let some of Senator Allison's comments pass. As Senator Allison is well aware, the Labor Party and the Democrats and the Greens came together before the election to indicate that we would all be supporting proportional representation for Victoria's upper house. We will certainly keep our word on that deal. I hope that down the track the Democrats, when they decide they are going to vote for it, will also keep their word about this deal.

speech.para: But I particularly find it galling for Senator Allison especially to stand up here and criticise Steve Bracks about his position on gambling, because Senator Allison is an individual who gave $10 million to Jamie Packer. This is an individual who improved the bottom line of Crown Casino when she walked out of the chamber to allow passage of some of the worst amendments you will ever see. They were called the GST high-roller amendments. When the five chicken Democrats walked out, they gave the government the numbers to pass the high-roller amendments, and that put $10 million in Jamie Packer's pockets.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Conroy is misrepresenting my position. I did not walk out of the chamber; I did vote on that occasion.
—That is not a point of order. Take it up at another time.
—It is a point of explanation, I believe.
—Do you get to give them nowadays?
—I hope you heard what Senator Allison said. I think she made a point.
—I seek a clarification. Are points of explanation allowed just whenever senators want to?
—Well, it is not a point of order.

—Thank you. I again make the point: when it came to the vote on the GST high-roller amendment that improved the profit margin of Crown Casino and Jamie Packer by $10 million, the five chicken Democrats took a walk out the door and the government had the numbers. It was all part of the government's cosy deal with the Democrats. So for Senator Allison to stand up here and pontificate about gambling taxation is just the height of hypocrisy.

speech.para: But I would like to move on to the substantive issues for debate here today. At a state and federal level the Liberal Party want to privatise everything that has not been sold. Prior to the state election, the Kennett government proposed the privatisation of the Ballarat water treatment works. We know that the Kennett government plans to privatise the rain. It wants to sell off the most basic resource to our lives—Victoria's water. A precious resource is to be given a dollar value and simply sold off into private hands, even foreign hands, forever. But the good news for ordinary Victorians is that all four of the Ballarat seats that were up for grabs, upper and lower house, voted against the government and voted Labor on the weekend. As I think the federal member for Ballarat said on radio a couple of days ago, he has to get in his car and use half a tank of petrol to find another Liberal—the Government Whip, Michael Ronaldson.

What are the ideologues in Canberra in the coalition saying to this proposal to privatise water supplies? They are supporting the National Competition Council, who are saying, `Sell' and are therefore claiming Mr Kennett has the right to sell our water. Of course during the election campaign Mr Kennett tried to get away with saying that he would not sell, but after last Saturday it is clear the electorate does not believe him and does not trust him or the coalition in Canberra on privatisation.

To avoid the debate on privatisation and other key election issues, the Liberal Party invented a new campaign technique—silence. Every Liberal candidate was gagged. And what was the response of the federal Liberal Party to this strange new election technique? Silence. Why was it that every candidate was gagged? Why was it that no federal minister was allowed to participate in the campaign? Was it because the Liberal Party policies were hopeless? Was it because the Liberal candidates were no good? I leave it to you to judge. Was it because Mr Kennett could not trust his federal colleagues? It was Mr Kennett who said, `I have gagged them because I don't want them wandering around like Brown's cows.' He is talking about elected representatives of parliament there to represent their voters, the people who elect them. And how does he describe them? `I don't want them wandering around like Brown's cows.' Welcome, Senator Patterson. I am trusting that Mr Kennett was not referring to you as one of Brown's cows.

The Labor Party and Mr Bracks wanted to debate, in any forum at any time, health policy, education policy, police staffing levels and government contracts, and the answer from the Premier down was: `We're not up to it; there is no debate.' Why was there no debate? The Liberals at a state level and the coalition at a federal level have been running down public health and education so quickly that they could not face a public debate during last week's state election campaign. The people of Victoria have sent the Liberal Party a very simple message: no comment, no votes.

The National Party last Saturday—and I am disappointed that Senators McGauran and Boswell have not stayed to defend the coalition in Victoria—lost the Assembly seat of Warrnambool to the Liberal Party and the Assembly seat of Gippsland East to an Independent. The National Party held only nine seats before last week in the Legislative Assembly and now they are down to seven and facing oblivion. What was the response of the Leader of the National Party, Mr Pat McNamara? `We now hold the balance of power and will stand up to Mr Kennett.' Does anyone believe Mr McNamara? He has had seven years to stand up to Mr Kennett and he is now challenging Senator Boswell for the title of the greatest rollover exponent in the country.

The former member for Gippsland East, Mr David Treasure, was asked this week to explain why he felt he had lost and his response was: `I don't know what they want.' This is a candidate in an election. He has just been defeated and he admits, `I don't know what they want.' Where has he been for the last four or eight years of his term? What we do know is that the two party preferred vote for the National Party in Gippsland East has dropped from 72 per cent in 1992 to 49 per cent last Saturday, and even members of the Treasure family are now working against the National Party. This is a seat the National Party has held continuously for over 70 years. It is no coincidence that it is also the area represented federally by the McGauran family. Perhaps Senator McGauran, who did not stay for the debate, can explain to the Senate why he is working so hard to bring about the demise of the National Party.

The new Leader of the National Party, the Hon. John Anderson, reflected on the weekend, amidst this calamity, as he said, that the National Party had not lost any seats to the ALP. Well, that is okay then! That was the best he could do in the face of this rout—they did not lose any seats to the ALP. He did not say that he would make sure Mr Kennett was brought into line. Why is this? The reason is that, like his federal colleagues, he would let Mr Kennett privatise all of Victoria's irrigation system without questioning it at all.

Every time Mr Kennett opens a new monument in the CBD in Melbourne the average Victorian parent is thinking about their child's overcrowded classroom or the time they had to wait in casualty at the local hospital. If they have the audacity to complain, they are told that they are un-Victorian and whingers. There is no debate and there is certainly no recognition that what they are claiming is their right. On all of these matters Mr Kennett has had the undivided support of his federal colleagues, except perhaps the Treasurer. But that is a different story for a different day.

In the Herald Sun on Monday, 20 September, Melbourne Major Events Corporation Chairman, Mr Ron Walker, took a dip at voters for pushing his close friend to the brink of defeat. He said, `The Premier has worked very, very hard to help this state regain its presence and it is true to say Melbourne today—indeed Victoria—is known throughout the world more so than the 1956 games and this is the thanks you get for it.' Mr Walker said, `Perhaps the older population felt they were disadvantaged and didn't accept change so much.' Does this sound like the voice of a person who has heard what the electorate is saying?

What Ron Walker is saying is that all Victorians need is a casino and a grand prix and they should be happy and go back to sleep. Well, the Victorian electors spoke on the weekend and Ron Walker is still deaf. Of course Ron Walker certainly did not hear the electorate say that they wanted to know about the casino tendering process and the cost of obtaining and running the grand prix. Nor did Ron Walker hear that there are too many gaming machines in this state or that there were problem gamblers at all.

Will the federal government implement the findings of the recent Productivity Commission report on the problem of gambling, or will Ron Walker, as federal Treasurer and bagman of the Liberal party, say, `I raised the money for the elections, so you'll do what I say'? Here is the test for Mr Costello. Here is his chance to prove what an undemocratic state Victoria has become. Implement the Productivity Commission report. It might mean a few dollars less for Ron Walker and Lloyd and his mates, it might mean a few dollars less for Jamie Packer, but then Mr Costello does not care. He has Lachlan Murdoch on board, as we all saw in today's papers. Here is your big chance, Mr Costello. Implement the Productivity Commission report.

You will all remember Mr Ron Walker. Ron Walker is the person who tried to stop Russell Skelton of the Age writing a story that Lloyd Williams had bought a block of flats in Paisley Street in South Yarra without a building permit or a planning permit. Ron Walker is the person whose chemical factory burnt down in Fitzroy in suspicious circumstances. Ron Walker is the person who, in conjunction with Lloyd Williams, bribed Norm Gallagher. Lloyd Williams confessed to doing so in the Winneke royal commission into the BLF.

Ron Walker is the person who arranged for a small commercial fit out company, Coulsen Constructions, to do work on the Premier's house. Ron Walker is the person who `persuaded' Mr Brian Quinn to move the Coles Myer headquarters from the city to the site of the old Toorak drive-in. Obviously no money changed hands, for Mr Brian Quinn is an honourable man—which is why he is currently serving time in jail for stealing from Coles Myer. As the former Town Clerk of the City of Melbourne said in summing up on Mr Ron Walker, `He would tell a lie when the truth would do.' Who is the Premier's closest friend and staunchest defender? Why, it is Mr Ron Walker, of course!

Why is it that no federal member of parliament in the coalition has called for the release of the casino tendering documents? Why did the government members on the casino inquiry try to thwart an examination of this issue? As Senator Carr well knows, he was gagged consistently by government members on this inquiry to make sure that the truth was not uncovered. Surely the Liberal Party has nothing to hide. When these documents are ultimately released—and they will be—what will we find that Mr Ron Walker has been hiding? Has he changed his spots, or is the Liberal Party corrupt from the top down? In the Bulletin this week in an article by Virginia Trioli—

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order.
—Are you saying it is not true?

—I am. It degrades this chamber to have those sorts of accusations made with nothing to substantiate them whatsoever. If the honourable member has anything to put forward rather than the inane ramblings of his own brain, I think that we should have some facts on the table. I do not think he should traduce people's personalities or their pecuniary interests in any way whatsoever unless he can produce some documentation. It does no honour to this chamber to come out with the verbal diarrhoea that is occurring at the moment.
—There is no point of order. As we all know, parliamentary privilege covers a host of matters.

—You can talk about John Elliott, the former president. If you like, you have the bagman Walker. I have spoken extensively about Elliott. He is a worried man, because the Swiss courts are releasing their documents in the next 24 hours.

speech.para: In the Bulletin this week an article by Virginia Trioli quotes the former Liberal Premier of Victoria, Sir Rupert Hamer, as saying that the electorate is calling for a more open, accountable form of government. Sir Rupert Hamer is also saying that the current Mr Kennett is not capable of changing his spots. On the John Faine program in answer to a question regarding Stephen Mayne's allegations—that is Stephen Mayne who was the former press secretary to the Premier and Treasurer—on secrecy in government and inappropriate share dealings, the Premier said, `I am not answering that question. I am going to just sit here and drink my tea. You're pathetic.' That was the Premier of Victoria responding to a question about probity put by a former employee of the Premier. If that does not demand an answer, what does? It is more evidence of the new campaign technique—silence, no debate; `I am going to drink my tea.' Mr Kennett was putting forward the proposition that, in an election campaign, he did not have to answer any questions and was not accountable to the electorate.

After the election, Mr Kennett talked about `the toenails of the state', referring obviously to rural Victoria because during the campaign he described rural Victoria as `the toenails'. I wonder which toenail Seymour is, which toenail Gisborne is, which toenail Ballarat is, which toenail Ripon is, which toenail Bendigo is and which toenail Narracan is. All of those toenails gave him a good kick on the weekend. Mr Kennett said on Wednesday 25 September, yesterday, `I wish to apologise to all those I have offended over the past seven years.' The Victorian community is saying, `We will accept your apology, providing you resign and disappear from public life.' The question the public is asking is, `Will his federal colleagues tell him to publicly go?' Here is the big chance for the Treasurer. He should have a quiet word in his mate's ear. Senator Tchen is here today. I think he is speaking today. Here is his chance to go to the bloke who put him in here, the bloke who rorted the Liberal Party preselection in the Senate to knock off Senator Synon. Here is Senator Tchen's chance to stand up and say, `Enough is enough, Mr Kennett. It's time for you to step down.'

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Conroy, you did reflect on a person rorting. I would ask you to withdraw that particular comment.
—I am sorry. It is Senator Synon who actually accused the Premier of rorting.
—No, you have to use the correct term.
—Cheating? Which is the correct term? I am talking about Jeff Kennett.
—You are saying the Premier now; you did not say it before.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. How much longer do we have to put up with this inane diatribe? There is no longer a Senator Synon. That is my point of order. It is illustrative of the inane ramblings of the senator opposite. Perhaps one day he might grow up and add some lustre to this chamber rather than doing what he is doing at the moment.
—Senator Herron, there is no point of order. But I would remind Senator Conroy that, when he reflects on a person in another place, that is out of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise point of order. I have been sitting in my office and now I am standing in my appointed place to draw your attention to the point of relevance. What we are discussing is the quality of services in Victoria and I would ask you to consider what Senator Herron has correctly described as nearly 20 minutes of inane rambling on any subject but, which has vilified many private citizens who simply have no comeback to the level of remarks that Senator Conroy has been uttering. I ask you to rule on the matter of relevance.

—Senator Troeth, I hear your point. I will have to rule against it because I believe that general business debates are usually very robust, and in this particular case Senator Conroy has been more robust than normal. But people on whom he has reflected do have a recourse and perhaps those people, when they read Hansard , may wish to do so.
—It is good to see one of Brown's cows has found their voice and that they have removed the gag.
—I think people out there who are listening to this debate would ask that you return to the matter at hand.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise another point of order: Senator Conroy has just used a term which was used in application to state members. I am a federal member, and therefore he should not use that term when referring to me.

—On the same point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: Senator Conroy made a derogatory remark about a senator. I mean, if `duffer' is unparliamentary, I would put it to you that this was a derogatory comment.

—I accept that it is a derogatory term, which is why it is so unusual for the Premier to describe his own ministers and his own candidates as `Brown's cows'. But I accept the implication and I withdraw the implication. It is disappointing, however, that federal senators and members of parliament in Canberra were not prepared to participate in the state election and show themselves. I spent some days campaigning in rural Victoria. It is disappointing.

speech.para: As I was saying, the Victorian community is saying, `We will accept your apology, Mr Kennett, provided you resign and disappear from public life.' The question the public is asking is: will his federal colleagues tell him to publicly go? Stand up, heed the message from country Victoria, heed the message of loss of service and tell Mr Kennett that it is time to go. Mr Gude has gone, Mr Stockdale has gone and Mr Knowles has been defeated. Who is there to lead—Victor Perton or John Richardson perhaps? Obviously there is a need for some federal talent—Senator Rod Kemp perhaps? A businessman—you guessed it, maybe Lloyd Williams is available for Frankston East's preselection. The fact is the Liberals are in disarray and the Nationals are terminally ill.

talk.start.para: —John Elliott?
—John Elliott is still not in jail. Perhaps he could stand.
—We have a good candidate.

—We got a seven per cent swing against them in the booth, Senator Troeth. Remember it is the Premier of Victoria who less than six months ago called for the sacking of the New South Wales Director of the Liberal Party on the grounds that he did not know how to campaign. Only six months ago the Victorian Premier demanded the resignation of the New South Wales party secretary. Well, what does he have to say about Mr Poggioli today? The only thing we can hear so far is the sound of shredders in Victoria as they shred their documents. That is the only sound we are hearing from the Premier.

speech.para: The coalition, state and federal, often say that they believe in less and less government. Too often that means less and less responsibility. Who is taking responsibility for basic family services in Victoria, decent schools and first-class health care? Where is the responsibility in a government that abandons the regions and the towns?

Mr Kennett talks about Victoria in 2050. What is that dream? He has a private dream—just like his federal colleagues—of zero government, zero responsibility, a dream that if it came true would be a living nightmare for all Victorian and Australian families. Has anyone heard Mr Kennett or any of his ministers say that they are proud of a Victorian hospital, proud of a Victorian school, proud of running an accountable government? Absolutely not.

Yet up here in Canberra we have the federal coalition running around saying publicly that Jeff is their man, that Mr Kennett is their choice to lead the party to the Frankston East by-election. And that is exactly what Senator Troeth has just done. Jeff is their man, their choice for the future. They expect him to manage the new political setting and relations with the National Party and with the Independents. Does anybody believe them? Certainly not Sir Rupert Hamer, certainly not the people of rural and regional Victoria where the ALP now has more seats than the Liberal Party and the National Party combined. This is truly historic: the Labor Party has more seats than the combined numbers of the Liberals and the Nationals.

talk.start.para: —Say it again.
—I will repeat that: Labor has more seats in rural and regional Victoria than the National Party and the Liberal Party combined.

speech.para: While Mr Kennett concentrates on the circuses in the CBD, our streets and suburbs remain neglected, and insecurity grows as our police numbers are wound back. What is the response from the coalition in Canberra? A resounding, `Go, Jeffrey, go.' Not the desirable, `Go, Jeffrey, for God's sake, go.' It should be `Go from public life, Mr Kennett.' But we get a ringing endorsement here today from Senator Troeth, a ringing endorsement from Senator Tchen and a ringing endorsement from Senator Patterson for Jeff. That is what we will see.

Imagine the state of our schools in Victoria if Mr Kennett were to lead for another four years. The Victorian school system is already the worst funded and most unequal in the country, and Mr Kennett's plan is to give up on the future of our kids and slide the state education system into private hands. That is what was exposed during the campaign.

The Kennett government has privatised the Mildura Base Hospital, the Latrobe Regional Hospital, the Berwick Hospital and is in the process of a world first—the first privatisation of a major teaching hospital, the Austin Hospital at Heidelberg. If Mr Kennett is allowed to continue he will further run down and then privatise the Geelong Hospital, the Ballarat Base Hospital and the Bendigo Hospital. Privatisation means profit for the owners and an uncertain future for families.

Victoria needs more police on the front line. The police went on strike at Frankston police station three weeks ago. That is right—they went on strike at Frankston police station three weeks ago. That is because Mr Kennett was not listening to the police in Victoria. It is the first police strike in Victoria since 1923. The community knows that we need more police; the victims of crime know we need more police. Everybody is in agreement except for the Premier and his colleagues here today who want to wind back further on essential services. That is what we are seeing today: a sycophantic endorsement of Jeff, ignoring what just happened on the weekend. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Thank heavens, Mr Acting Deputy President, that father time has relieved us of that diatribe from the other side. I have to say that it is a shame that Senator Robert Ray has gone to the UN—I am sure he has been contributing to the UN mission to Australia. Since his hand—the hand that guides Senator Conroy—has gone to the UN, Senator Conroy has been over the top. His performance in this place has been appalling. Bring back Senator Robert Ray to bring him into line, I say. Fortunately we were not on air today so people did not have to be subjected to what I think was appalling behaviour and an appalling contribution in this chamber.

speech.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr said, `Burst our eardrums.'
—Senator Conroy, could you resume your seat, and could you keep the noise down a bit? I am trying to hear what Senator Patterson has to say.

—Senator Robert Ray has, time and time again, come into this place and said, `It's 10 steps to coward's castle.' And it was 10 steps to coward's castle for Senator Conroy today when he vilified person after person—people who have no ability to reply, except through the Privileges Committee of this place. The Privileges Committee is overworked because of the sorts of comments made by people like Senator Conroy. Senator Conroy has been to the Privileges Committee a few times and, with Senator Robert Ray out of the place, he will be there a lot more often.

speech.para: I think the topic that the opposition have chosen for today, the general business order of the day in relation to the parallel between the policies of the Kennett and Howard governments and the quality of services in Victoria, is indicative of the state of the federal Labor Party. When we were in opposition we used this time to put forward our concerns about their policies—gee, we had a lot of concerns about those—and to put forward our policies. What do we have today? Not one positive thing from Senator Conroy. Not one thing that Labor will do for Victoria, federally or on a state basis. It was a diatribe of vitriol about individuals. It was a speech—although you could hardly call it a speech—that told us nothing. It was a rave that told us nothing about what they were going to do either federally or from a state point of view for the state of Victoria. It was a gloat about winning seats in Victoria, but there was nothing about what the Labor Party would do for the people of Victoria. Senator Conroy said, `Imagine the state of our schools if Mr Kennett were to lead Victoria through the next parliament.' I say to you: I do not want to think about what would happen to schools if Labor were to lead the state.

talk.start.para: —Jeff Kennett closed nearly 400 schools.

—I went to a school out in Berwick, in Robert Dean's electorate, and I was there when the federal government and the state government put money into refurbishing that school. The president of the school council said that eight years before—Labor was in government—water had been coming up through the floor and leaking through the roof of the school. The only sadness the president had about her daughter no longer being in the school was that her daughter went through the primary school when it was in that condition under Labor—she did not actually say `under Labor'; it was just that her daughter went through the school at that time—and her son came into the school the next year and benefited from all the refurbishment and the other things that had been undertaken in that school. I have been to school after school in the areas of Victoria which are developing and expanding, and I have seen new schools being built and schools that were run down under Labor being refurbished. I would encourage some of my colleagues on the other side to go out to those schools and see what is being done.

speech.para: As I said, the ALP have wasted their time in this place in attempting to drag along a debate that they failed to sustain on Monday. They went on about this when they had an opportunity in taking note of answers to questions. But, again, in that debate there was not one positive or constructive idea about what they would do in government—federally or from a state point of view—for Victoria. This is an attempt to deflect the attention of the public from the fact that the ALP totally lack policies—they are totally a policy free zone, both in the state and federal spheres.

Let us put this ridiculous motion in perspective by enlightening people and reminding them of the state of affairs in Victoria prior to the election of the Kennett government. I think people forget. I went to South Australia a year after the Kennett government had been elected. There was a Labor government in South Australia. I could not believe it. I had forgotten how bad Victoria was. I had forgotten that, when you went down the streets, shop after shop had signs saying `To Let', that the unemployment levels in rural and regional areas were astronomical and that businesses were closing down.

I remember going to New Zealand and going into a Clipsal factory. I was told, `Oh, we've shifted the factory to New Zealand because we can make Clipsal items such as light fittings cheaper here in New Zealand than we can make them in Victoria, and we ship them back to Australia via Japan.' That was the state of things. Victoria was a basket case. As I said on Monday, the joke going around was: what is the capital of Victoria? Ho, ho, ho—$1. People were fleeing Victoria. Victoria's population was decreasing. I can understand why people wanted to leave: they left Victoria because there were no jobs, there were no prospects and there was no hope. If you looked at Victoria in the early nineties, you would have seen it was in an appalling state. It was let down by successive inept ALP governments. Unemployment was out of control. Debilitating industrial disputes were crippling the ability to provide adequate community services. There was the State Bank of Victoria—one of the senators on the other side talked about privatisation.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —At least we actually had assets to sell off. The State Bank was in demise. We did not have it to sell. The Labor Party talk about privatisation. They sold the Commonwealth Bank at a federal level, and what did they do? They spent the money. They did not use it to retire debt; they spent the money. That is the record the Labor Party have. They either let an asset deteriorate to the point where it is worthless and they have to get rid of it or sell it and use the money for recurrent spending. That is totally unacceptable. The next generations will live to rue the day that they did that. What did the Victorian government do under Jeff Kennett?
—They did not want to see the water system privatised.
—Yes, it sold assets, but it did not use the money on recurrent spending; it used it to retire debt. I remember sitting in a tram going from the School of Nursing to Lincoln Institute—
—That's been privatised too.
—Order! Senator Carr, you have interjected 14 times during this speech. The previous Acting Deputy President sitting here had the same problem. If this continues I shall report it to the President.

—People always shout and use personal abuse and vitriol when what somebody is saying hurts them. The louder he shouts, the more obvious it is that I am hurting him. Mr Acting Deputy President, I appreciate your support, but it really demonstrates that I am hitting where it hurts.

speech.para: As I said, I was sitting in the tram next to someone. She turned over her Herald Sun—`VEDC collapses'. The woman next to me said, `It doesn't matter. It's only the government's money.' But whose money was it? It was the people of Victoria's money. Tricontinental was another wonderful success of the Labor state government! Remember Tricontinental? Victoria was a basket case. It was a rust bucket.

Having adopted Victoria as my state, I walked around Victoria as late as the last week or two and I looked at the city, and I have to tell you it is sparkling. There is development everywhere. It looks tremendous. If you go out into the rural areas, you will see change there too. I will remind people about what happened. I said on Monday that I hope Victorians do not rue the day of the last state election. If the vote falls that way and there is a minority Labor government, they will sadly be reminded very quickly of Labor's record. There was zero confidence, zero security and investment and zero vision.

I just want to remind people of something that was said by a colleague of mine about the situation in Victoria under the Kirner government. Federal growth in jobs was 19 per cent, whereas in Victoria it was just 13.9 per cent. In February 1982 the unemployment figure in Victoria was 6.7 per cent, while in the rest of Australia it was 7.2 per cent. By February 1992 in Victoria it had blown out to 12.3 per cent, while in the rest of Australia, starting from a higher base of 7.2, it was still only 11.3 per cent.

Jobs were lost in Victoria at the rate 3.5 per cent, compared with 1.1 per cent for the rest of Australia. Unemployment in Victoria rose at the rate of over 30 per cent, compared with 22 per cent for the rest of Australia. We were going down the tubes federally, but Victoria was going down the tubes faster than anywhere else. The number of unemployed people between the ages of 15 and 19 looking for their first full-time job increased by 73 per cent in Victoria, compared with just 49 per cent in the rest of Australia. We were leading the country—going down the tubes faster—with unemployment, especially youth unemployment. The number of unemployed people between the ages of 15 and 19 looking for a full-time job rose by what? It was 51 per cent in Victoria, compared with 22 per cent Australia-wide.
What a litany of mismanagement under Labor. Is it any wonder that former senior cabinet minister Neal Blewett—and this makes really interesting reading—said in 1991:
Credibility is gone in Victoria for state Labor.
Or that he recounted the following from a 1991 cabinet debate:
Keating had claimed doggedly that we are still in charge of events—
How misled he was! He said:

Keating had claimed doggedly that we are still in charge of events; we are not yet in Kirner's hopeless situation in Victoria . . . while Hand pointed out that confidence in the government and the ALP is utterly lacking in Victoria. Cook suspected that the ACTU is already making plans for survival under the Liberals.
I want to remind Victorians that that is what it was like. My former colleague Julian Beale was prescient when he said in 1992 to the parliament:

The damage caused to the Victorian economy by federal and state Labor government has been disastrous, but it can be repaired. The first prerequisite is a change in government in Victoria and a change in government federally. Confidence will never be restored in Victoria while we have state and federal Labor governments, and confidence is a necessary prerequisite for the return of investment and the creation of jobs.

And that is exactly what happened. In the face of this desperation—in stark contrast to ALP governments—the state coalition governments since Cain and Kirner have created an environment for growth and a better quality of life for all Victorians. When the Kennett government came to power in Victoria, Victoria faced an incredible debt of $30.6 billion. This was clawed back to $11.3 billion by the end of 1997, and it was projected to fall to around $8 billion by 2001. What Mr Kennett wanted to do—and he said this right back at the beginning—was to give young people in Victoria the same opportunities he had when he was growing up. That was not being given to young people in Victoria when they were standing to inherit a debt of $30.6 billion, increasing at an ever-increasing rate, and when assets were being lost—not sold; lost—and no money was going back into the state as a result of those assets just dissipating.
Let me just go through some of the achievements of the Kennett government—

talk.start.para: —Why?

—Why? Because when they came into power in Victoria, Victoria was a basket case. She can crow all she likes from the other side, `Why?' I want to remind Victorian people because people do forget. They forget how bad it was. I had forgotten how bad it was. I had forgotten how appalling the state of Victoria was, how appalling the debt was and how appalling the situation was in the state in terms of schools and hospitals. I went around to nursing home after nursing home. Those state nursing homes were a disgrace. You should not have put a dog in some of the nursing homes they had. There were 10 people to a ward. They had done nothing to upgrade the nursing homes. She can sit here and ask, `Why?' Why? Because I want to remind people of how bad it was when Labor was in government in Victoria.
