speech.para: The Kennett government allocated $1 million to community carers to look after family members and friends with disabilities. They guaranteed to maintain pensioner concessions. There was preparation, through the inquiry by the suicide prevention task force, for the introduction of a strategy to reduce the rate of suicide, especially among young people. That suicide prevention strategy involved $24 million per year to reduce the incidence of suicide, particularly for those in higher risk groups. There was a significant expansion of disability services, including training, vocational and cultural programs, and the establishment of community residential homes with full-time support staff. There was funding of $17 million to provide care and services for street kids. I could go on and on. There was none of this borrowing from the next generation. This was money that was not racking up debt for the next generation.

When I went round to rural and regional areas, in many of them small hospitals were being totally refurbished. Some of the other achievements in health included, in the past year alone, the opening of the Northern Hospital in Epping, the La Trobe regional hospital at Traralgon, and the Broadmeadows hospital and health service. There were new hospitals scheduled to commence construction in Mildura, Berwick, Knox, et cetera.

The record of the Kennett government was one of fiscal responsibility. It was one of bringing Victoria back into the black. We saw an increase in population, with people returning to Victoria as a result of that. We saw the implementation of a major program for environmental protection and the creation of new parks, including the Yarra Ranges. There was the consolidation upgrading of the natural assets at Phillip Island into a single park. There were new grasslands parks in central Victoria. There was a new strategy to protect the Port Phillip Bay and Victoria's coastline.

Senator Mackay might ask why I am saying this. When speakers on the other side have got up, they have failed to remind people of how bad it was in Victoria before Jeff Kennett and the coalition government came in. They also failed to tell us what they were going to do. What I have done is to demonstrate the record of the coalition and what has happened in Victoria. They have no suggestions. All I can presume is that we are going to go back—if the dice fall that way—to the bad old days: to borrowing to pay for spending and to having parents say the water was coming up through the floor of the school and the water was coming through the roof. I could not believe that. I was stunned when I heard her say that. I could not believe the schools were in that state. I want to put on the record the things that have happened rather than this vitriol about individuals.

Well in excess of $300 million was allocated to the community support fund for arts, tourism and sports projects, large and small. That was not just in Melbourne; that was in rural and regional areas as well. There was the opening of regional performing arts centres and there was support for regional galleries. There was support for family and youth services and a campaign to combat drug use.

Small business saw a reduction in regulation and compliance requests. That was an important factor for small business. I was handing out how-to-vote cards and this young painter came up and said, `For heaven's sake, I hope Jeff wins because it has helped me in my small business.' I am sure, when I contact him, he will be devastated by the outcome. There was the introduction of $50 million partnerships for growth programs to attract new industry and investment to country centres to strengthen existing business and finance new community projects. It was a legacy of activity and a legacy of development. It was not the sort of legacy that Labor left of debt, of despair and of no ideas. The debate today has given me no hope that Labor has any ideas for the future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Patterson has been telling us about some of the good things that happened under the Kennett government. I might even add to that. I thought he was right on the approach he took to the One Nation party. I thought he was right on migration. But I can point to many good things that Mr Cain did when he was Premier, particularly in the area of the justice system. There were good things that Ms Kirner did when she was in government.
—In education.

—In the education department particularly, as Senator Carr would know. I have now lived through many elections over my life, not only state and federal elections but also elections within the party—always conducted with the utmost propriety. I have been in that party or in that particular faction that has lost, and I have always chewed the cud and analysed why we should not have lost.

speech.para: The fact of the matter is that it is a `to do' loss, and what you have to do then is look to the future and plan what you think is best for your state, your party, your faction or your country. The people of Victoria do not owe the Liberal Party, the National Party or the Labor Party any particular favours. You enter the field of politics and try to get into government to serve; and to take the approach that somehow the people of Victoria are—

talk.start.para: —Ingrates.

—Ingrates—thank you, Senator Mackay—or are in some way wrong is just not the proper way to look at the issue that now faces us. To take an example outside the Labor Party, I read in today's Age about an Independent who has won Gippsland East. Mr Treasure, who formerly held that seat, explains all the reasons why the Independent should not have won; but the fact of the matter is that he did. Mr Ingram won, it seems—to a large extent in any event, from what he says—because he wants the Snowy River to run free. That is a matter of the spirit.

speech.para: We have heard analysis from the other side about the economics of this and the economics of that; but, besides the bottom line, there are other matters that people are interested in, and that is what Victoria has shown. They are interested in properly planned suburbs, so that houses are not allowed to be built in a way that takes the sunlight away from the backyards in which they live. There are all sorts of issues and to concentrate just on the economic issues is to miss the point.

Whatever the people of Victoria saw, they saw something good in the Labor Party and something good in Mr Bracks and his team. I would like to congratulate him on his speech at Ballarat. Senator Carr was there, and Senator Carr does a lot of work in Ballarat. I thought Mr Bracks's speech was full of propositions. It has been put here today that we as a Labor Party in Victoria have got no plans, but we have got lots of plans—plans about the fundamentals that people want from government.

When I talk about education, health and proper policing, I am mentioning words that have been said in this place again and again as representing what the people want. Those words are used again and again because they are true. That is what people do want. It has been said from the opposite side that there are now shiny new shops in Melbourne and this and that, but what has happened in the country? Whatever we might think here, the people in the country have said, `We are not being brought into the community in the way that we should.' That is what they have to say. They say, `We live in a society with lots of other people, and we want a share in the resources of that society and in the benefits that that society can bring.'

The Labor Party lost badly in Victoria in 1992 and again in 1996. Senator Carr would remember that, as he lived through it with me. They are not nice times when you have to come out of defeats like that. People talked about the fact that we had lost because of the way that money had been treated. When the analysis is made of this election, when the euphoria and disappointment have passed and we are able to approach it in a more logical way, the way that the Kennett government has used money might well be an issue. I do not mean it is an issue of propriety; I mean this: I do not think that people object to paying taxes. What they object to is their money being misspent or not properly looked after. If you spend money from taxes on good schools, good hospitals and good policing, they are willing to contribute to that and will do so.

I think we are going to have a very interesting debate in this chamber and in this parliament about what the Age calls the `Ralph revolution' with capital gains taxes slashed. The issue is not whether you tax people but whether you tax them fairly and whether those taxes are used appropriately. To simply say, `We do not tax you as badly as you might otherwise have been taxed' is not the issue. The issue is about these fundamental services that any decent society would want. They are interested in their taxes being used in an appropriate fashion.

I do not want to name them all, but I think a tribute ought to be paid to Steve Bracks, John Thwaites and the team. This time last week, they were people who were going almost to disappear from the face of the earth. This week, they have made a great contribution. Also in this context, I mention the trade union movement in Victoria, which have performed quite brilliantly throughout the time that the Liberal government has been in operation. I illustrate that with the way they have led in Melbourne the marches against the Indonesians and in favour of the East Timorese. I think that Leigh Hubbard needs special mention in that context.

The time has just about gone. This debate is about the future and not the past. The people of Australia have seen the future in Steve Bracks and his team, in much the same way as in 1972 the people of Australia saw the future in Mr Whitlam. When they saw that they were right, and when they see it in Mr Bracks they are again right.

subdebateinfo.title: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 26 August, on motion by Senator Bartlett:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak briefly to this Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report. It is a significant report. As honourable senators would know, the Democrats have spoken for many years about the need to improve the treatment of gay, lesbian and bisexual people in Australian society. There are still wide ranging areas of discrimination. As my colleague Senator Greig outlined in his excellent first speech a couple of weeks ago, this discrimination has very real impacts on many people throughout the Australian community.

speech.para: There is no logical rationale for that ongoing discrimination. This report addresses one of those areas—which is the superannuation entitlements of same sex couples—and it examines federal legislation. I urge all senators to examine the issues that are contained in this report. It is a fairly straightforward report, because in many ways it is a straightforward issue. Perhaps in years gone by, when there was less of a social understanding or acceptance of de facto couples, the concept might have been a bit harder for people to wrestle with. But, clearly, to suggest that there should be some fundamental difference between de facto heterosexual couples and same sex couples is absurd. There is no social or legal justification for such a differentiation.

Clearly, there are many people who are disadvantaged by the fact that their sexual orientation is what determines the fact that they cannot access their partner's superannuation and that they have fewer entitlements than others in the Australian community. It is a fundamental and clear-cut area of unjustifiable and inappropriate discrimination and one that leads to a significant proportion of the Australian population being discriminated against unfairly. On behalf of the Democrats I urge all members of all parties in this chamber and in this parliament to support moves to address the areas of discrimination such as the one outlined in this report from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

It is probably appropriate that I also mention the Democrats' private senator's bill that has been in this place for over three years now—originally introduced by former senator Sid Spindler. It has been the subject of a comprehensive Senate committee inquiry which produced a lot of helpful information. The passage of that legislation would address not just this problem of superannuation entitlements of same sex couples but also many other areas of unfair discrimination. I also urge senators and, ideally, eventually members in the other place to lend their support to that legislation in order to address the issues that are raised in this report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator O'Brien:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I speak very briefly in order to have this matter leave the Notice Paper , although I am certain that the matters I referred to when this was before the Senate yesterday will resurface in other areas. I take note of the fact that, following my contribution yesterday, Senator Ian Macdonald rose to his feet and said he felt constrained to defend the minister. Whilst I am not surprised that he felt so constrained, it has to be said that the only way he could sustain five minutes of speaking time was to spin off a couple of matters that Senator Forshaw raised by way of a point of order. But the reality was that he had nothing to say about the matters I raised in relation to Mr Forsyth's letter—the letter which com mences the corporate plan report which was laid before the Senate.

speech.para: I remind the Senate that this was a letter dated 11 February 1999, a letter which apparently, like many other things, had been lying for some time on the desk—perhaps on the return or on a side table or in a cabinet—of Mr Anderson, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. In seeking that we take note of the report, I simply say that, if my comments have been a spur to the minister to address some of these issues quickly, then so much the better. But if these issues are not addressed quickly, the minister can be sure that I will be rising to my feet in this place to draw the attention of the Australian public to the inaction of this minister on critical transport issues which face this nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 2 September, on motion by Senator Carr:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the response to this report—and not only for the reason that the response has been lodged. The report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration into the working holiday makers scheme, entitled Working holiday makers: more than tourists , was presented to the parliament in August 1997. Here we are in September 1999, two years and one month later, and we get a response to the report—a report on a matter that the minister himself initiated that there should be inquiry into. There is a convention around the place, which I know is not rigidly adhered to, that the government respond to committee reports within three months. Nobody in the chamber expects that that will be adhered to on a rigid basis, but I think that having to wait two years and one month for a response is perhaps an indication that things could be done better than has been the case on this particular occasion.

speech.para: The working holiday makers scheme, as the committee identified, is a very important element of Australia's tourism program. It is also of great importance to various sections of industry that depend on these people from time to time to fill holes in their labour market programs. The government response to the report is welcome, but in itself it is not enough. We are awaiting the report of Mr Noel Hicks. Mr Hicks has been commissioned by the government to look into other elements of what I believe to be part of the working holiday makers program; that is, those elements dealing with transient workers in the agricultural industry—the fruit picking industry. Mr Hicks has been commissioned to do some research and present the minister with a report. Unfortunately, we have no details of whom Mr Hicks has spoken to, where he has travelled and whom he has received submissions from. We are not even sure that the report by Mr Hicks will see the light of day.

I think it is very unfortunate that so many things are now being done in secret by the government. I do not think this leads to good policy development. I was of the opinion that a different body, perhaps even the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, could have undertaken the task that Mr Hicks has been engaged to undertake. Indeed, if the committee had undertaken that task, it would have been conducted in public. The community right across Australia would have been invited to participate in it. I have no knowledge whatsoever of Mr Hicks having any involvement with those involved in Western Australia in that very important element of the program. Anyway, that is an aside from the government response to the report.

The committee worked long and hard in developing the 41 recommendations in the report, which were put to the minister. I am pleased to note that the majority of the recommendations have been accepted by the government. While they have been accepted, however, not all of them have been accepted in full. But it is pleasing to see that the government is at least taking some interest in what the committee put forward to it. That some recommendations have not been accepted is also quite appropriate because, in developing the recommendations that we put to the government, we endeavoured to engage it in the thought processes of more policy development in this area. There were other recommendations which the government did not accept and, as I say, that is part of the policy development area as well, which is quite acceptable to us.

Another area which also probably deserves a mention is the work being commissioned by the minister in appointing the chair of the committee, the member for Hindmarsh, Mrs Chris Gallus, to chair a working group. The working group will oversight the progress and implementation of the harvest trail. Again, this is being done by Mrs Gallus, it is a working group of the government and there is no involvement of the parliament, as such, in its work. I am sure that Mrs Gallus will do a very thorough job of it, but it is a task that probably could have been undertaken by the committee as a whole. Others in the parliament would then be able to have an input into the work that is being done. I would hope that, when that report and Mr Hicks's report are completed and presented to the minister, they will be made public—or, at least, presented to the parliament in order that they can be made public—so that others who have a big interest in this area will be able to give some scrutiny to the work that was undertaken and to any recommendations that may develop from that work.

talk.start.para: —I would also like to speak briefly on the government response to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration report on working holiday makers. As Senator McKiernan noted, the response has been a long time coming. Like Senator McKiernan, I am also a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, but I was not involved in the preparation of this report because it was brought down before I came into this place. While it feels like I have been here for an eternity, it is slightly less than two years—but that is still a fair while. I think that is more than adequate time for a government response. While it was a fairly comprehensive report, it was not a set of encyclopedia, and I think it should have been able to be responded to more promptly.

speech.para: Not having been part of the initial inquiry, I would not seek to say I have extensive knowledge in this area of working holiday makers. But an important and often overlooked part of our migration program is not just working holiday visa holders but temporary visitors of all sorts. Whilst tourists are often not seen as migrants—and in a technical sense they are not—people applying for visitor visas are part of the operation of our laws that relate to enabling people to enter and leave the country and the restrictions and requirements applying to that. Working holiday makers are no different in that regard. There are some areas of overlap in terms of principles and issues that apply across the board. Whilst oftentimes in this place, the Democrats and I focus a lot on refugee and humanitarian issues, which seem a long way removed from working holiday visas, some of those principles do have similarities across the board in terms of fairness of process.

One of the recommendations that was not accepted—and I can understand the rationale, but I think it is still worth highlighting—was that nationals of non-agreement countries involved in the working holiday program be eligible for a working holiday visa if they can satisfy appropriate bona fide checks and are aged between 18 and 25. There was also a recommendation that a cap be introduced on the number of working holiday visas to be granted to nationals of non-agreement countries, with the cap set at five per cent of the overall program number.

Not having been part of the committee's deliberations, I would not want to completely speak on what the motivation for those recommendations was. But from my point of view from reading them, it seemed like a very sensible approach of trying to ensure there is at least some small amount of input from non-agreement countries. The agreement countries at present are limited to Canada, the UK, Ireland, the Netherlands, Japan, Korea and Malta. The committee felt there are a lot of other countries in the world outside that group of seven whose people would benefit—and so would Australia—if a wider range of people were able to come to this country under this program.

The feeling I get from the government's response is that not only do they not want to have a five per cent cap but they are moving further away from offering visas to non-agreement country nationals. They are trying to extend the program to other countries, which is a good thing, and they want to emphasise the issue of reciprocity—where we allow people in from particular countries if those countries allow Australians in. That is a principle I would agree with as well.

Nonetheless, I do believe that enabling a small number of people in from non-agreement countries is important. I have a small concern that some of the broader countries outside those agreement countries are developing countries. It is beneficial for Australia and for the individual person to come here on those sorts of visas, and it is also beneficial for them to be able to go back to developing countries and take part of what they have learnt from Australia, which could be of assistance to those countries.

I have expressed in this place before some concern about what appears to be an approach which makes it harder for people from particular countries to get visitor visas of any type into Australia because of a heightened level of suspicion on the part of the department that those people are more likely to overstay, breach the terms of their conditions, come here and seek a protection visa or things such as that. Whilst I do not suggest those concerns should not occupy the thoughts of the department at all, I do feel they have been overemphasised in recent times. I wonder if a bit of that feeling is spilling over into the government's response in relation to people from non-agreement countries getting working holiday visas. I do not know if that is the case; I simply flag it as a hope that it is not and a concern that we ensure it is not. People on working holiday visas from developing countries can offer just as much to Australia as people from the UK, Canada and Ireland, and I think it would be beneficial to Australia to have a broader range of people from different nationalities able to access this program.

The government, I suppose, would argue it is going down that track somewhat more slowly but more coherently by trying to expand the number of agreement countries. I recognise that and do not have a problem with it, but I do express a bit of disappointment that, if anything, a further reduction in the number of people from non-agreement countries is going to occur. Potentially, eventually, not allowing any at all appears to be a possible implication one could draw from the government's response here, which I think would be a shame. Nonetheless, it is pleasing to see the government has responded positively to many recommendations, but it would be better if it had responded positively somewhat quicker.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 2 September, on motion by Senator Carr:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I should start this speech by commending the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs for responding much more rapidly to the Immigration detention centres report than the previous report. This report was presented to the parliament in August 1998, and here we are 13 months later and we get a response to it. Part of the reason for such a speedy response might be that this report was only 41 pages in length and made only two recommendations. So maybe the commendations I am giving to the minister and his department are not quite as fulsome as they ought to be. I think the report could have been responded to much quicker than it has been.

speech.para: There were only two recommendations made in this report and I want to address both of them. I will deal with the second one first. The second recommendation stated:
The Committee further recommends that during the next parliament the JSCM consider conducting an inquiry into the immigration policy aspects of the detention of illegal fishermen.
The brief government response, which is well worth reading into the record, states:

The Commonwealth Ombudsman released a comprehensive report concerning the role of the department in the detention and removal of illegal fishermen in 1998. In August 1998 the government announced proposed improvements to current fisheries and detention arrangements to address the recommendations contained in the Ombudsman's Report. These improvements include changes to legislative and administrative arrangements for the detention of illegal fishermen and the implementation of some of the Ombudsman's recommendations including substantial improvements to the facilities for detained fishers at Broome and Darwin.

The developments announced by the government substantially address the concerns expressed by the JSCM in their current report. It is not appropriate for the Committee to duplicate work already undertaken by the government.
I do not accept that response. I think it is highly appropriate that the parliament oversee, view, examine and scrutinise the work of government, particularly the work of government in this area.

For my state of Western Australia, the state I represent in this place, it is a real problem. Only last week the Attorney-General, Mr Peter Foss, announced that the prison in Broome was overcrowded with illegal fishers. The repercussions of that were that local offenders or offenders from the region who were sentenced to imprisonment had to be incarcerated in detention facilities away from Broome. Sure, they have to be detained somewhere, but that meant their relatives, the people who wanted to visit them while they were in detention, had to embark on long journeys. Why? Because the detention facility in Broome was overcrowded.

Another reason why the committee ought to consider having a look at this particular aspect is a matter that was reported on the ABC Four Corners program very recently—on 23 August, I believe. Some persons who had come to Australia to fish illegally had been apprehended, detained and sentenced. One of them said that he did not have a problem with being detained in Australia because it was rather like being treated to a hotel—one got steaks, one got ice-cream, one was very well treated; and I have made some comments on this matter before.

The matters remain with us, and they are of great concern if others can profit from coming to Australia, breaking our laws and being detained but being paid while they are in our detention facilities. I am certainly sure the joint standing committee will consider the government's response and will seek to address what is in here. They might encourage the minister to give the committee a reference on this matter.
The other recommendation the committee made was about monitoring, and it states:

The Committee recommends that the JSCM continue to monitor detention practices and suggests that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs request that the Committee again inspect the facilities during the next parliament.

The minister has agreed to this, and there obviously is a great need for the committee to do this. The great need is what is occurring in our detention facilities currently. At the time the joint standing committee visited the detention facilities, on 17 June 1998, there were 394 people in detention. Currently, there are over 600 people incarcerated in the Port Hedland facility on its own. Quite recently, that facility was very close to capacity with only a few spare beds. It was virtually overcrowded. At that stage, the department was looking for another facility where other illegal arrivals might be detained. The circumstances have changed dramatically from the time the committee visited the facilities in order to prepare this particular report.

Other things have happened as well. In all detention facilities around Australia, there have been big problems, problems that have led to dramatic headlines. I will quote just a few of them: the Australian of 23 July: `Ombudsman to investigate refugee mistreatment claims', and it was referring to the facility at Perth airport; the Perth Sunday Times of 25 July: `Detainees riot for four hours'; the West Australian of 26 July this year: `Police end barricade protest by detainees'; the Australian of the same date: `Detention centre escape in spotlight'; the West Australian of 27 July: `Mass breakout from Port Hedland'; the West Australian of 28 June—which is actually going back a bit earlier—`Break-out at Port Hedland'; the Age of Saturday, 31 July: `Fear grips Refugee City, WA'; and the Australian of 28 July: `Illegal immigrants run wild—and free'.

They are mainly talking about Port Hedland, where there was some real difficulty, but there were also some problems at the Maribyrnong facility in Victoria, where quite a substantial amount of damage was done. The matters there are subject to an inquiry by the Commonwealth Ombudsman because some people were removed from that detention facility and incarcerated in other places. The matter is still under investigation. There was also a very large escape from the Villawood detention centre in Sydney. I think 11 persons escaped from that particular facility, not all of whom have been apprehended and returned to custody—or, to use the department's term, recamped. There are some difficulties with the detention centres.

The Senate Standing Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, which I chair, has not reached any conclusions on this current inquiry, but it has been diverted from the work that was given to it because of very serious complaints that were made to the committee by detainees at certain centres. The complaints were so serious that we could not overlook them. We had to divert from the 13 terms of reference that were specifically given to us by the department to investigate those complaints ourselves.

On one particular instance I, as chair of the committee, referred one particular complaint to the relevant police forces for their inquiry. It was something that I felt at the time was much bigger than the committee itself. It was not our role to investigate possible criminal conduct. The committee will further deliberate on these matters and will reach conclusions. Incidentally, on that activity I undertook as chair, the committee endorsed my actions in referring the matters to the police. The detention policy and regime of the government is something that has to be constantly kept under scrutiny by the parliament of Australia and indeed by the community of Australia.

talk.start.para: —I would also like to speak to the government response to the Immigration detention centres report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, which, as I said in my previous contribution, I am a member of. I was here at the time this report was presented and was part of the preparation of the initial report. I again echo Senator McKiernan's comments that, whilst there was only one year for this response to be done, one year seems a pretty long time to respond to two recommendations, neither of which, I would have thought, are particularly complex. They are pretty straightforward recommendations. It does not send the most positive signal for the government to take over 12 months to respond to such basic recommendations.

speech.para: I would mainly like to address the recommendation which relates to the need for ongoing monitoring of the operation of our detention centres. As part of the preparation for the initial report, I visited the Port Hedland detention centre, the Perth airport detention centre and the Villawood detention centre in Sydney. Unfortunately, I missed the one in Melbourne. One of the things that highlights how quickly things can change in this area is that when I undertook those visits, which were probably in the first half of 1998, the Perth airport detention centre, which is quite a small establishment, was, in my view, unsatisfactorily crowded with quite small and inadequate facilities, particularly for such a large number of people, some of whom were there for more than 12 months. The Port Hedland facility at that time was pretty damn empty, as I recall.

talk.start.para: —It had 25.

—It had some 25 people in it. It was almost a ghost town, yet now it is bursting at the seams again. These things can change quickly. Obviously, the types of services, the ability of service delivery and some of the factors that need to be addressed in terms of managing the population of detention centres can vary a lot. There are lots of problems that can arise when you have large numbers of people in a facility. There are very different but nonetheless very real problems when you have very small numbers as well. For that reason, it is important to have fairly regular monitoring of these facilities.

speech.para: The whole issue of detention centres for illegal non-citizens is a vexed one. The Democrats have often expressed the view that we need to work more diligently and put a bit more effort into increasing the number of people that we allow to enter the community. It would be cheaper for the taxpayer, except where people pose an unacceptable risk, and more appropriate for the people involved as well. Nonetheless, the government does not take that approach. It takes a much more hard line in the number of people it believes should be kept in immigration detention. For that reason, we do have facilities that do get overcrowded at times and we do have people in them for exceptional periods of time.

The Senate committee has been looking recently at the onshore humanitarian program and people applying for protection visas in Australia, many of whom spend time in these detention centres while they are applying. They are not convicted of any crime; the only act that has led them to be in these detention centres is that they are an illegal entrant or an illegal non-citizen. But many of them end up accessing and being granted a protection visa, and Australia has an international obligation to provide that protection visa.

Many of those people have obviously undergone a fair bit of ordeal in their countries of origin. It is often not the best experi ence for them to have the continued ordeal of spending an extended period of time in a detention centre which, for all intents and purposes, could be equated with a jail—not a maximum security jail by any sense of the imagination, but nonetheless pretty similar to imprisonment. There is not much of a difference between imprisonment and detention. You are kept in these places and are basically not allowed out. There is a lot of similarity between them in terms of atmosphere. So it is an important issue because it affects people. It is not just a matter of public policy. It is public policy that impacts on real people, many of whom have already undergone quite an extensive degree of suffering.

As I said, it is a vexed issue. I am not trying to paint it too much as a black and white picture, but I do think that, again, as I have said on a number of times recently, including in this chamber, when we are balancing all the factors in our humanitarian program and immigration program, one of the factors that has somewhat moved into the background in recent years which does not have a strong enough weight in the equation of balancing all those competing issues has been the issue of compassion and a humanitarian approach. Detention centres provide one example of that. I do believe that there is room for a bit more compassion in relation to this issue.

Nonetheless, I welcome the government's response to the recommendation and its agreement that the committee should be enabled to conduct further inspections of the facilities. Even with the brief visit I had at Villawood with the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee a couple of months ago I could clearly see a few changes that had occurred in the 12 months since my previous visit, the most obvious of which was an increased amount of razor wire around the place, which does not necessarily add to the cuddly feeling of the place.

talk.start.para: —They're trying to keep them in.

—It does try to keep them in. I could clearly see what the purpose of it was and no doubt it is believed there was a justification for it. But, again, that is an indication of the way these centres have changed over time. Detention centres have changed a lot over time, as I understand it. When places like Villawood were first used for this purpose I do not think there were any fences at all. Clearly the need to increase security has occurred, and I would not necessarily argue with that, although I do not resile from my comments before that I believe there is more room for enabling a greater proportion of these people out into the community. Be that as it may, we are addressing the reality of government policy at the moment in the operation of detention centres. I am pleased to see that the Joint Standing Committee on Migration will be able to continue to conduct that role. That committee is one that I believe operates in quite a constructive way across different party lines and it does try to address what all parties agree is a difficult issue in a constructive way.

speech.para: I would hope that the government also takes a constructive approach to deliberations and recommendations of all parliamentary committees in this area because I do believe it is one where we do try to operate constructively and try to avoid some of the more inflammatory aspects that can easily be followed if one was of such a mind in this area. I do think there is a bit more room for the government, recognising that there is actually the possibility of room for improvement in some areas, to be a bit more open to suggestions from parliamentary committees such as this one in that regard.

talk.start.para: —The government's response to this report has been a very praising one. In its overview of the report, the government says:

speech.para: The focus of the report is on providing a description of the physical conditions at immigration detention centres and the services currently provided to immigration detainees. In contrast to the reports issued by other agencies, the Committee's report is overwhelmingly positive. The report comments favourably on the conditions in immigration detention centres and the efforts made by the detention services provider, ACM, to provide appropriate services to detainees.

The reading of that brought to my mind that something has to be addressed—that is, how can there be such a stark difference between the reports from the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, made up as it is of good people in the parliament, and the report of the Australian National Audit Office and the report from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission entitled Those who've come across the sea ?

It is difficult to see what the situation really is, not because of the lack of goodwill on the part of the people who have written these various reports but because of the lack of the sort of material that one would hope to find in the reports. The report from the Joint Standing Committee on Migration says that the committee considered that the `facilities were adequate' and the `services were of an appropriate standard'. What does that mean? What is adequate? I would have hoped that the committee would have set itself some criteria against which it could make its measurements. What do I mean by that? Well, how big are the rooms in which these people are held? There are some photographs in the joint committee's report and one of the photographs shows that there are four people to a room. That might be good or bad. What is the size of the room? You can see bunks one on top of the other. They seem to be in a very confined space. What was the measurement of the space they were in? What was the measurement of the beds? How high were the beds? These are the sorts of questions that you would ask about any prison.

I often have a discussion with people from DIMA about whether or not these people are imprisoned or detained. I am always assured that they are not imprisoned. Clearly, I would have thought it was contemplated that these people would be at least as well off as those who are in prison. If you want a report on prisons you would want to know what the size of the various facilities were. I hope that when the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, a very eminent committee, goes to visit these places of detention in the future it sets itself some criteria against which it advises us as members of parliament what the situation is so that we can work out for ourselves why the committee should come to such a different conclusion from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and from the Australian National Audit Office.

My other concern is that these people are detained by private contractors. I have to confess to a prejudice here. I have always considered that if the state is going to lock people up then the state should take responsibility for that, and to allow private profit to arise out of imprisoning people or detaining people is always a matter of some concern. I hope that when the committee comes back to us again on the next report it says something about that. I notice that it considers that the making of profit is not a bad thing even if it is made out of detaining people. I can understand its point of view, but perhaps there is another alternative to that. In paragraph 2.32 the committee states:
The centre represents the third largest enterprise in the community, generating as much as $1 million per annum for the local economy.

Does the committee mean that we should have these people detained to increase the local economy or is there some other reason? How much do these private detainers make out of this contract? I would have thought that was of some importance because it gives us an idea of how many people are likely to be in there.

As I said the other day, I have discussed these issues by letter with the minister. He says that, in the interests of peace and good order, the details of the contract should be kept confidential. That is the approach taken. I think, on the other hand, that we as members of the public are entitled to know what Australasian Correctional Services Pty Ltd and Australasian Correctional Management—they call themselves ACS and ACM—are charging. From that, we can get an idea of what sorts of staff numbers they might maintain. How many people are looking after these detainees? If you were looking at prisons—and there has been an attempt to find out about details of prisons in Victoria—you would want to know the economy of the place so that you could estimate whether there were enough people to ensure security. The previous speakers have talked about people escaping from these places. How many people were there when they escaped? What was the quality of their training? Were they trained properly? Were they employed on a part-time or full-time basis? What is the state of the staff at these places?

I hope when the committee goes out again it gathers us some details of these quite important points so that we, as members of parliament representing the people of Australia, are able to tell them how their money is being spent in terms of these prisons. People are coming from overseas. That is another issue. We have decided as a parliament that these people should be detained but, as Senator Bartlett says, we have to remember at the same time that these people are not even charged with an offence—they are absolutely innocent people—and they will not be charged with an offence. They will be sent back. It is a very serious matter to lock anybody up, whether it is a local person or a person from overseas. It is a great violation of people's bodily and mental integrity and should not be done lightly. If it is done, it should be done so that the public generally know how it is being done and on what basis.

I invite the committee in future visits to look at these issues: the size of the cells; the amount of money that is being spent there; the level of the staff, particularly when we have these people escaping as they seem to; the qualifications of the people who are in charge; and just what relationship there is between those people and the people who plan these things at the top.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: The following orders of the day relating to committee reports and government responses were considered:

Privileges—Standing Committee—78th report—Possible improper use of proceedings of Community Affairs References Committee. Motion of the chair of the committee (Senator Ray)—That the Senate endorse the findings contained in paragraph 34 of the 78th report of the Committee of Privileges—agreed to.
Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee—Supplementary estimates report, June 1999.

Reference to committee: Motion of the chair of the committee (Senator Crane)—That the recom mendation contained in the committee's report, to refer issues raised in the report to the Procedure Committee, be adopted agreed to.
Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts References Committee—Report—Commonwealth environment powers. Motion of Senator Bolkus to take note of report—agreed to.

talker.name: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator George Campbell)

talk.start.para: —Order! There being no further consideration of government documents, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Honourable senators will recall my addressing the Senate on Wednesday, 1 September with regard to a very large predicament in the potato industry in Tasmania as a consequence of a potato disease scare raised by Western Australian quarantine offices. Three russet burbank potatoes, part of a small consignment from Tasmanian to Western Australia, had been identified as possibly carrying the exotic disease bacterial ring rot. I am pleased to report that the outcome, after extensive tests and investigations, proved that there was no substance to the allegation. In fact, tests on DNA of the disease, specifically brought in from Canada for matching, proved beyond any doubt that the disease was not bacterial ring rot. The good news, unfortunately, was tainted. The massive overreaction has sinister political overtones.

speech.para: I have already brought to the Senate's attention the transfer of Simplot's potato tonnage from Western Australia to Tasmania and the trouble with quarantine documents for potatoes from Tasmania entering Western Australia since that date. It also appears that Western Australians became very angry when potato cyst nematode, or PCN, was found to exist in their state because this put the lid on them selling potatoes to other states which do not have the disease. I inform the Senate that Tasmania does not have potato cyst nematode, but Tasmanian potato growers have unfortunately been victimised.

This very foolish exercise by Western Australian quarantine officers has brought the possibility of an exotic potato disease existing in Australia to the world's attention. How absolutely stupid! The damage done by this exercise will be absolutely enormous. Now producers from all over Australia wishing to export will have to try to explain the situation to likely buyers. It is extremely difficult to undo this type of damage and along the way it costs the industry very dearly. All Western Australian quarantine officers involved in this scam should hang their heads in shame.

The officer who found the first potato was inexperienced in the identification of potato diseases and, without a sound second or even third opinion, the Western Australian media were notified. The whistle was blown loud and clear, far and wide. ABC radio in Tasmania was advised by ABC Western Australia that a consignment of Tasmanian potatoes was suspected of carrying or having bacterial ring rot. In the absence of any positive identification of the disease, this action was totally irresponsible. The Tasmanian farmers are not amused. In fact, they are hurt and they are angry.

Both the farmer who grew the potatoes and the packer who shipped the potatoes have been disadvantaged financially. The packer has been affected considerably because the two containers that landed in Western Australia, the two containers on the water and 200 tonnes of potatoes in his warehouse were all quarantined. The two containers on the land and the two on the water could not be used until the whole mess was cleared, but by that time the potatoes, having been stored inappropriately, went soft and they sprouted. They were wasted and thrown out. Some of them were unusable before that time anyway because, after finding one suspect potato, quarantine officers in Western Australia cut two tonnes of potatoes in half trying to find further evidence. But no further evidence was found.

The farmer not only suffered financially but also suffered health wise. The stress was enormous, and he became stricken with shingles. As well as farming he has a contracting business, and the machinery that was not on his farm at the time was being used on other farms. Owners of those farms became paranoid—not surprisingly—that their property could catch the alleged disease, even though nothing had been proven.

The disease had never before existed in Australia. I repeat: never before! And one inexperienced quarantine officer caused this monumental problem with immeasurable damage. I say: that person should be sacked. But what about compensation? You can bet the Western Australian department involved will not pay for it. There is no precedent for compensation being paid and probably no likelihood of it being paid. The irony is that if the disease had been found, then compensation would have been paid. Approaches by the packer to the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industries, David Llewellyn, were unanswered until an assistant returned his call—not the minister himself. This is an insult to one who has suffered so much, and none of it from his own wrongdoing. The Tasmanian Premier's department was also contacted, but it has not even bothered to return the call. The national body must closely investigate this case. The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Australia is responsible for export controls on primary industries products.

There are many questions to be answered: why was a very loud panic button pressed after only one suspected potato was found in a consignment of two shipping containers, especially when the disease was not known to exist in Australia? Why weren't experienced quarantine officers called in to check the suspect find? Why was such a hasty decision taken? Why weren't the Tasmanian quarantine officials given the opportunity to comment on whether or not it was likely for bacterial ring rot to have been found? Why was the packer in Tasmania notified of the problem by his buyer, not the department of primary industries in Western Australia or even the department in Tasmania? Why did it take five days for a sample of the suspect potato to reach the Tasmanian laboratory for testing? Why were the results of the first test inconclusive—indeed, what were the testing procedures? Is there a need for a better and more rapid identification system? Precisely so.

Why did it take exactly three weeks from the time of the quarantine being implemented to it being lifted—and that was the day after I raised it in the Senate, incidentally; three agonising weeks for the Tasmanian potato industry? Why all along the way did Western Australian quarantine officers and department officials frustrate the situation? Those involved in Western Australia knew what they were doing. The issue is very political from an agricultural point of view, with Western Australia trying to protect its own industry. I believe the whole issue was quite disgraceful. I thank the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I have listened very carefully to what Senator Watson had to say and I am concerned about the matters that he has raised. It is very serious when you get sick spuds in the community, and the actions of the various officials in the different states are a real cause for concern. So I join with you on that. But that was not the subject matter of what I wanted to talk about tonight.

speech.para: I want to pay tribute to a very dear friend who has passed away and whose funeral took place in Perth today. Unfortunately, I was unable to be present. Dick Keegan was a mentor of mine when I first became active in the trade union movement in the first instance and in the Australian Labor Party in the second instance. Dick was one of nature's gentleman who was much respected within the trade union movement but he also earned the respect of the various employers that he had to negotiate with on behalf of the people who employed him as a member of the then federated engine drivers union.

Dick was a member of the Australian Labor Party since 1946. So well over five decades of service was contributed to the Labor Party in Western Australia by this wonderful gentleman. He was a full-time union official with a variety of unions including the FEDFA—the union I met him in in the first instance—for other 20 years, having previously served as a shop steward at the Bunbury power station. By his efforts on behalf of workers not only in his own union but also in many of the other unions—including the iron ore industry in which the FEDFA was a prominent organisation—he earned the respect of all those that he met.

When he gave his word on some matter in negotiations, everybody—the other unions, the convenors, the shop stewards, the employers, the industrial officers and the industrial relations commissioners—knew that his word would stick. It was very dear to Dick that when he gave his word it meant something. That was something that did not apply to all the industrial officers and employer representatives—and, indeed, some union officials—that I met during his lifetime.

I developed a very close relationship with him, particularly in 1979 during the time the then Court government instigated and used that infamous section of the Police Act, 54B, to incarcerate workers in Western Australia to halt union meetings. It was an effort to destroy the trade union movement in that state at the time. Dick was one of the stalwarts in that very inflammatory situation where there was direct confrontation between the trade union movement of the day and the then state government, aided and abetted by the Fraser government, which was in power in Canberra at the time. Running alongside those infamous 54B battles was a very large dispute that was occurring with Hamersley Iron at three sites right across the Pilbara—at Dampier, Tom Price and Paraburdoo. It was a strike of some 10 weeks in duration which cost the company enormous amounts of money but cost the community, the state of Western Australia and the export sector of Western Australia even more. All through the course of that particular dispute Dick maintained his integrity and maintained a commitment to those that employed him. He did that with very great integrity, despite the fact that there was much provocation from all sides. He was one of the stabilising forces during that particular time.

He is survived by his wife, Lily, and other members of his family, who will, I am sure, miss him dearly. We in the trade union movement and in the Australian Labor Party were privileged to know Dick and to work with him, but his family got the better of the job—they had his love in a way that none of us can match. Obviously they will miss him a great deal more than we do. On behalf of my Western Australian Labor Party colleagues, I express condolences to Lily and other members of the family on his sad passing, and our regrets that we were not there at the funeral today to pay our last respects to him.
Another matter I want to very briefly mention during this adjournment debate is the decision of the Senate today to agree to the motion moved by Senator Calvert:
(a) notes the tragic destruction caused in Taiwan by the earthquake on 20 September 1999, with 1 546 people confirmed dead, 3 841 people injured and 2 304 people unaccounted for;
(b) expresses sincere sympathy to the people of Taiwan affected by the earthquake and to those who have relatives injured in the quake; and
(c) expresses hope that relief efforts will be quick and effective in restoring essential services to the affected areas.
I think it is appropriate that the Senate did pass that resolution today and that it be conveyed to our very dear friends in the Republic of China that Australia as a nation is standing by them.

I omitted in my very brief contribution—by leave of the Senate—together with Senator Knowles, to record the fact that Australia is also contributing to the relief effort. A number of members of various emergency organisations around the country are going up there to assist: Gary Littlewood, from Queensland Fire and Rescue; Wayne Staples, from New South Wales Fire and Rescue; Martin Vandersanden, from the ACT Fire Brigade; Mark O'Connor, from the Metropolitan Fire and Emergency Services Board of Victoria; and David Kemp, from the South Australian Metropolitan Fire Service. I got excited when I saw the name `David Kemp' in the first instance; I thought it might be somebody else. But I am very pleased that Australia is making a contribution to this great tragedy that has beset the country. As I said in my brief contribution this morning, it is not just one earthquake that has occurred; two other earthquakes have happened since. The full extent of the damage is not yet properly realised, and probably will not be for many weeks to come until the outlying and rural areas are able to report in, because of course communications have been damaged in some areas. I was told last evening that it was known that 300 people were trapped in buildings at the time and tremors continued to occur. The figures that Senator Calvert put in his motion this morning had, even before the motion had passed the Senate, grown in number, and I am certain that they continued to grow throughout the day and will do so in the immediate weeks to come.

I think it is pleasing that Australia is standing by our neighbour in this tragedy, as we have in other recent tragedies in Turkey and Greece as well. I expressed the sympathy of the opposition parties in joining with the government this morning.

talk.start.para: —I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate the determined work of a small group of volunteers based in the western Queensland township of Charleville. The Save the Bilby Fund has embarked on a project that is attempting to halt the decline of the bilby by establishing a protected breeding colony in the Currawinya National Park near Hungerford in western Queensland.

speech.para: Bilbies are a desert dwelling bandicoot about the size of a rabbit, with a coat of soft grey and tan hair. However, the bilby's most distinctive feature is their very long ears. Many in the house may remember this feature from the Easter Bilby campaign, which attempted to raise the awareness of Australians to the plight of this unique creature. Of the six bandicoot species that once lived in the arid to semi-arid areas of Australia the bilby is the only species remaining. However, it too is in decline. The bilby formerly occupied much of eastern Australia west of the Great Dividing Range. Sadly, it has now vanished from New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. Bilbies are now found only in sparse populations in isolated desert areas in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland.

In Queensland the bilby population has dwindled to a mere 300 to 700 in an area stretching across some 100,000 square kilometres from Birdsville to Boulia. This vast area once supported a much larger and healthier bilby population. Mature breeding female bilbies usually produce only one to two young at a time. Unfortunately, this relatively low birth rate has been no match for losses inflicted by introduced predators such as the red fox, feral cats and wild dogs. Competition for food between introduced and native species in these harsh arid areas has added further pressures on the bilby population.

The Save the Bilby Fund has developed a plan which it hopes will halt the decline of bilby numbers and result in renewed bilby populations once again spreading throughout their previous natural habitats. The Save the Bilby Fund, with Frank Manthey and Peter McRae at its heart, plans to take a small breeding colony of bilbies based at Charleville and place them in a purpose-built enclosure designed to protect the colony from predators and reduce competition from other species. Once bilby numbers have reached a satisfactory level within the enclosure, it is intended to gradually allow some of them to return to the wild. This will boost the wild population, while securing the nucleus of the breeding colony.

Frank Manthey and his helpers in undertaking this project clearly demonstrate the determination and perseverance that is at the heart of those who live in rural and western Queensland. The sheer scale of the project would deter most people. The enclosure which will protect the bilbies at Currawinya will consist of a 25 square kilometre, two-metre high fence that is predator and feral animal proof. The size of the project is daunting and so is the cost. The total cost of this project is expected to be about $300,000. To ensure that this project is successfully completed Frank Manthey and the Save the Bilby Fund will need more than just determination and perseverance; they will require the financial assistance of all of those who claim they are committed to saving our endangered wildlife and of all of those who claim they are friends of the bush.

When I visited Charleville recently I had the pleasure of meeting Mr Manthey and some of his helpers. I saw first-hand how Mr Manthey has gone about raising approximately $60,000 for this project so far. He has done this by running bilby information nights, encouraging donations and actively seeking the support of the local community. Visitors to Charleville are invited to come to the National Parks and Wildlife station where the current bilby population is based. Mr Manthey then gives them an entertaining and informative talk on the bilby. He then shows these visitors the bilbies in their natural state under red floodlights which illuminate the bilbies' area without causing them any discomfort. After this display is over, he then sells various types of merchandise to raise funds, a particularly hard slog that he has to go through.

Mr Manthey also asks for a $20 donation. Those who donate the $20 effectively pay for one panel of the enclosure fence. Each donor will be officially recognised on site at the Currawinya National Park in a leather bound book permanently housed at the site. Donors also receive a certificate of appreciation from the fund. Larger donations from corporate organisations are gratefully accepted by the Save the Bilby Fund. Indeed, during my visit to Charleville it was my great pleasure to be present when Mr Gary Ryan from the Queensland Branch of the Australian Workers Union presented Mr Manthey and the Save the Bilby Fund with a cheque for $500. This clearly demonstrated the AWU's support for the bush and our endangered wildlife.

It is in the spirit of this donation that I invite all senators to also dig deep and make a substantial contribution to the Save the Bilby Fund. The burden of raising the funds and driving this project is too much to expect from a small group of people, no matter how determined. They certainly need our help in this endeavour. It is a worthwhile endeavour, and I encourage all to participate. So, as I stated earlier, this is a chance for all of those who claim they are committed to saving our endangered wildlife and for all of those who claim they are friends of the bush to stand and deliver.

talk.start.para: —This afternoon under general business the Senate considered a motion by Senator Carr that the Senate notes the result of the Victorian state election. I sat in the chamber and listened to the debate because, as a senator for Victoria, I naturally have an interest both in the election itself and in what people say about it. I particularly note that in the course of the debate Senator Allison made some quite relevant comments and observations about the election. She said basically that there was a protest vote and the result of the election was a judgment by Victorians of the coalition government of Premier Kennett.

speech.para: She acknowledged that the Kennett government came into government in 1992, at a time when the Victorian economy and the society as a whole was in dire straits. But she said that the government had failed to recognise that it had caused hardship in the course of curing these ills and, therefore, had disappointed certain sections of the community that the good it had done had not been even and had ignored some parts of the community. Given the result of the election, obviously this view is shared by a number of people, particularly those in Victoria.

talk.start.para: —It was 51.5 per cent.

—I heard Senator Conroy's comment, but I think he ignored the fact that in this election there has been no winner. Although the coalition has not succeeded in regaining government in a straightforward manner, the result of the election is not yet settled. What is clear is that the Labor Party has not won. In Mildura, for example, which has been held up as one of the areas in which the Kennett government has failed, the Labor candidate polled eight per cent of the vote.

speech.para: The Kennett government was forced to carry out some quite drastic policies to restore the wealth of Victoria. Yes, it hurt. Surgery always hurts. Quite correctly, Senator Allison pointed out that it was Labor that was responsible for putting Victoria in that situation. But she was not generous enough to recognise the difficulties that the Kennett government had to overcome to put Victoria on its feet again. As I said before, she is obviously not alone in making this mistake. She was wrong to say that what you might call a shortcoming but what I would say was an inability to make sure that everyone recovered at the same rate was not recognised by the Kennett government or by the Liberal Party.

The need to look after the part of Victoria which has not been treated as well in the recovery process is a matter which the Victorian Premier is well aware of. I would like to take this opportunity to read something to the Senate. It is a speech Mr Kennett gave on 5 September when launching the Liberal Party campaign:
. . . I start today by thanking all Victorians for the opportunity and responsibility that you have given my colleagues and I over the past seven years to govern Victoria. . .
This is a task which at times has required a firm but always a fair approach to meet the circumstances in order that we could restore Victoria's financial, economic and social foundations. . .
The singular achievement of this period is that we now have a state and a people that are again confident and proud of our place within the Commonwealth of Australia. . .

This is a state which we have all together created, and of which all I believe we can be truly proud. It is true that not everyone has agreed with everything we have done, or the speed of change, particularly in those early years. But the result is a revitalised and an employed state with great prospects for the future.
He went on to list a number of things that he intends to do if he and his government are re-elected. One reads:
Fourthly, to use the resources generated by Victoria's new found economic strength, to reach out to those who suffer insecurity or feel alienated and hurt.

He said it was necessary to concentrate on those parts of Victoria that have not done as well, in particular rural and regional Victoria. Mr Kennett identified a particular thrust of his new government should he get re-elected, saying he would appoint a senior minister to drive rural and regional strategy with a whole of government focus and give rural towns due priority in terms of business development and employment growth objectives. He would also ensure that government services met the social needs of people in country areas and that there would be the necessary funding. It is not the case that Jeff Kennett or his government were not aware that some parts of Victoria had not done as well as others during the recovery process. I emphasise it is a recovery process. The Premier was well aware of it when he went into the election.

In his speech during the debate, Senator Cooney very correctly pointed out that the focus of our consideration should be characterised, in terms of looking at this election, not by looking at the past but by looking to the future. On this point, I would like to quote the final section of Mr Kennett's speech. He said:
On September the eighteenth we will ask all Victorians not simply to vote for the next government but to vote for Victoria's future for the next ten years.

The election is over and the votes have been cast. We still do not know the result yet but, for the sake of Victoria and for the sake of Australia, I firmly hope that enough Victorians did get the message.

talk.start.para: —I rise to make some comments this evening about the South-East Queensland Regional Forest Agreement which was recently announced in Queensland. Senators will have heard how well this agreement has been received by the community in general and, in particular, by the stakeholders involved. The agreement provides an outcome which provides protection to the forests of south-east Queensland and a strong economic future for the rural communities where timber milling is a significant industry. This agreement safeguards the jobs in the timber industry, not only for the immediate future but for many years to come.

speech.para: A total of 425,000 hectares will be added to the conservation reserve system. Importantly, much of this will be conserved in relatively large areas, which is a very important achievement for the protection of wildlife. Many fauna species require large areas of forest intact for their long-term survival. The key conservation areas that are being saved include the Conondale Ranges, the Mapleton Forest in the Sunshine Coast area and the Kroombit Tops area near Bundaberg. These areas contain magnificent forests, and their addition to the conservation estate will leave a lasting legacy to the individuals and groups who have played a part in this agreement.

I would like to take a few minutes to share with you some of the comments of those people and to acknowledge the work of those individuals and groups who played a part in bringing this agreement to fruition. First of all, I would like to congratulate the Queensland Conservation Council for their goodwill and participation in the deliberations. I quote from a media release that they issued on that day:
The Agreement, to which QCC is a signatory, represents the most important decision for the protection of Queensland's biodiversity for a decade.
That is a pretty strong endorsement of the agreement. The Wilderness Society should also be congratulated for their very positive contributions. They said:

Governments all around Australia should take a close look at the solution to the long running forest impasses developed here in Queensland. Too often the differences between the conservation movement and the timber industry are portrayed as irreconcilable. This agreement proves that this does not have to be the case.
They also pay credit to the Queensland Timber Board:
. . . for being the first Industry body in Australia to recognise that it is no longer environmentally or socially responsible to continue to log old growth and wilderness forests.

I think those comments show a level of goodwill and appreciation of each player's contribution to the discussion. I would particularly like to acknowledge the work of Dr Aila Keto, who has patiently and forcefully represented the interests of the environment for many years in Queensland. Her comments were:
It is not a compromise between industry and conservation but a path forward to positive outcomes to both.

She is supporting the view that many have expressed, that the agreement is a win-win for all. I also congratulate the Australian Workers Union, the Aboriginal native title representatives—FAIRA, the Goolburri Land Council, and Gurang Land Council—the Forest Protection Society, local government in the area, and the managers and employees of local sawmills.

All players have congratulated the Queensland government, and I add my congratulations to Premier Peter Beattie, Deputy Premier Jim Elder, and Minister for Environment Rod Welford, for the inclusive and cooperative manner in which they have steered this agreement. This style of decision making is characteristic of our government in Queensland, which is working towards bringing our community together, not tearing it apart.
I also congratulate the Queensland Timber Board. I quote from their press release dated 20 September:

It is worth repeating that this level of resource security is unprecedented in the history of the Queensland timber industry, and the communities, politicians and mill workers should realise that and give due recognition to this historic agreement.

In that quote, the Queensland Timber Board called on politicians to realise and give due recognition to this historic agreement. I suggest that Wilson Tuckey, the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, take the advice of the Queensland Timber Board and, instead of writing mischievous letters to the timber millers of south-east Queensland as he has recently done, take his responsibilities seriously and start to work with the Queensland government, the conservation sector, the timber industry and our community.

Mr Tuckey's letter is a letter of 2½ pages. At the outset he says that he is keen for a mutually agreed outcome for the forests of south-east Queensland which meets industry and conservation objectives. He says there would be a `considerable contribution' of federal funds for that agreement. He then says that he has not received advice from the Queensland government about the plan, so he is writing to the timber millers and requesting by return mail details of how the plan will affect their particular mills.

His line of questioning is, at best, patronising; but in all probability his intent is to undermine the Queensland regional forestry agreement. He asks a range of questions about the proposed source of the timber, its size, quantity and quality. If I were a timber miller in south-east Queensland, I would be offended by what Mr Tuckey seems to be implying: as if the Queensland Timber Board and its constituent timber mills would have signed off on an agreement if these matters had not been assessed.

Given that he himself advises that he has not seen the agreement, I find it interesting that he then spends most of his letter predicting what the agreement might include. He asks a range of questions about the legal implications of making such a decision. He wants to know how big the trees might grow in 25 years, and provides his personal expert advice—saying that the trees he saw in south-east Queensland on his last trip were not as big as the ones he has seen in WA that are 19 years old. I would respectfully suggest to Mr Tuckey that he wait until his government receives advice from the Queensland government and then request his department to make an assessment of the agreement.

Unfortunately, the Queensland Deputy Premier is correct when he has to advise that the Queensland government is speaking directly to the Prime Minister because Mr Tuckey has marginalised himself, because Mr Tuckey ends his letter by saying that the agreement `is not a sustainable solution and not in the long term interests of the forest industry'. Given that he says that he has not seen the agreement, how can he come to this conclusion?

Mr Tuckey's letter should be seen for what it is—a grubby attempt to undermine the agreement which has been welcomed by all of the stakeholders as a historic agreement. We have seen his achievements in Western Australia: his success in splitting the Liberal Party, pitting the state against the Commonwealth, playing an instrumental role in ensuring that the forests see violence, and pitting workers against their communities.

Mr Tuckey's portfolio includes forestry and conservation. He may not be able to under stand that the two can co-exist, but Queensland can. We request that he work with our government and our community towards the outcome that we all agree is best for our state.
